news|last1=Costa|first1=Robert|title=Sebelius: Some Take Rhetoric as 'Call to Action'|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/257031/sebelius-some-take-rhetoric-call-action-robert-costa|accessdate=24 December 2015|publisher=National Review|date=January 12, 2011}} {{Clear}} ==Expressed views== ===Views on politics=== Records show that Loughner was registered as an [[Independent (voter)|independent]] and voted in 2006 and 2008, but not in 2010. Loughner's high-school friend Zach Osler said, "He did not watch TV; he disliked the news; he didn't listen to political radio; he didn't take sides; he wasn't on the [[Left-wing politics|Left]]; he wasn't on the [[Right-wing politics|Right]]." A former classmate, Caitie Parker, who attended high school and college with Loughner, described his political views – prior to his 2007 personality transformation – as "left wing, quite liberal."{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/09/us/politics/09shooter.html?pagewanted=all | work=The New York Times | first1=Eric | last1=Lipton | first2=Charlie | last2=Savage | first3=Scott | last3=Shane | title=Arizona Suspect's Recent Acts Offer Hints of Alienation | date=January 8, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/01/10/loughners-meltdown-began-adulthood-near-say/ |title=Loughner's Meltdown Began In Adulthood, Those Near Him Say |publisher=Fox News |date=January 10, 2011 |accessdate=January 25, 2012}} The tone of Loughner's online writings and videos from immediately before the attack were described by an [[opinion piece]] of [[The Guardian]] as "almost exclusively conservative and anti-government, with echoes of the [[populist]] campaigning of the [[Tea Party movement]]".{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/09/jared-lee-loughner-rightwing-rants |title= Jared Lee Loughner: erratic, disturbed and prone to rightwing rants |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=January 9, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2017}} Mark Potok of the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] said that Loughner's position that currency not backed by a [[gold standard|gold]] or [[silver standard]] is worthless was a "hallmark of the far right and the [[militia movement]]."{{cite news |last1=Johnson |first1=Kirk |last2=Kovaleski |first2=Serge F. |last3=Frosch |first3=Dan |last4=Lipton |first4=Eric |title=Suspect's Odd Behavior Caused Growing Alarm |newspaper=New York Times |date=2011-01-09 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/10/us/10shooter.html }} [[Jesse Walker]] of the [[American libertarian]] magazine ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'' expressed deep skepticism at the connections drawn by Potok.{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Jesse|title=Unpacking Jared Lee Loughner|url=http://reason.com/archives/2011/01/20/unpacking-jared-lee-loughner|work=Reason.com|date=20 January 2011|language=en}} In the aftermath of the shooting, the [[Anti-Defamation League]] reviewed messages by Loughner, and concluded that there was a "disjointed theme that runs through Loughner's writings", which was a "distrust for and dislike of the government." It "manifested itself in various ways" – for instance, in the belief that the government used [[Language planning|the control of language]] and [[grammar]] to [[Newspeak|brainwash people]], the notion that the government was creating "infinite currency" without the backing of gold and silver, or the assertion that [[NASA]] was faking spaceflights. ===Dislike for Gabrielle Giffords=== According to a former friend, Bryce Tierney, Loughner had expressed a longstanding dislike for Gabrielle Giffords. Tierney recalled that Loughner had often said that women should not hold positions of power.{{Cite news |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/scocca/archive/2011/01/17/maybe-jared-loughner-was-a-bigot-after-all.aspx |first=Tom |last=Scocca |date=January 17, 2011 |title=Maybe Jared Loughner Was a Bigot, After All}} He repeatedly derided Giffords as a "fake". This belief intensified after he attended her August 25, 2007 event when she did not, in his view, sufficiently answer his question: "What is government if words have no meaning?" Loughner kept Giffords' [[form letter]], which thanked him for attending the 2007 event, in the same box as an envelope which was scrawled with phrases like "die bitch" and "assassination plans have been made". Zane Gutierrez, a friend, later told ''[[The New York Times]]'' that Loughner's anger would also "well up at the sight of [[United States President|President]] [[George W. Bush]], or in discussing what he considered to be the nefarious designs of government." ===Conspiracy theories=== His friend Zach Osler noted that [[Conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]] had a profound effect on Loughner.{{cite web|last=Herreras |first=Mari |url=http://www.tucsonweekly.com/TheRange/archives/2011/10/14/occupy-tucson-starts-saturday-9-am-armory-park |title=Occupy Tucson Starts Saturday, 9 a.m., Armory Park | The Range: The Tucson Weekly's Daily Dispatch |publisher=Tucsonweekly.com |date=October 14, 2011 |accessdate=January 25, 2012}} He was a member of the [[online message board|message board]] ''Above Top Secret'', which discusses conspiracy theories; members of the site did not respond warmly to posts believed to be from his account. Loughner espoused [[9/11 conspiracy theories|conspiracy theories about the 9/11 attacks]], the [[New World Order (conspiracy theory)|New World Order]], and believed in a [[2012 apocalypse]], among other controversial viewpoints. Reports appearing after the shooting noted similarities between the statements made by Loughner and those publicized by the [[Far-right politics|far-right]] [[conspiracy theorist]] [[David Wynn Miller]]. The Anti-Defamation League's report also confirmed Loughner's longstanding interest in conspiracy theories. ===Views on religion=== Journalists had speculated that Loughner was [[Antisemitism|anti-Semitic]] due to his attack on Rep. Giffords, who is Jewish, but the [[Anti-Defamation League]]'s analysis of the messages by Loughner found that he had a more generalized dislike of religion, and of government. A police report noted that he had previously been caught making graffiti associated with Christian anti-abortion groups.{{cite news|last=Hendley |first=Matthew |url=http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/news/fbi-agent-said-jared-loughner-made-graffiti-used-by-christian-anti-abortion-groups-6645853 |title=FBI Agent Said Jared Loughner Made Graffiti Used by "Christian Anti-Abortion Groups" |newspaper=[[Phoenix New Times]] |date=2013-03-28 |accessdate=2016-06-16}} Loughner has been described as an [[anti-theist]] by those who knew him.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/who-is-jared-loughner-friends-reveal-alienation/ |title=Who is Jared Loughner? Friends Reveal Alienation |publisher=CBS News |date=2011-01-10 |accessdate=2016-06-16}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/jared-lee-loughner-grew-delusional-in-months-before-tucson-rampage-police-reports-show/ |title=Jared Lee Loughner grew delusional in months before Tucson rampage, police reports show |publisher=CBS News |date=2013-03-27 |accessdate=2016-06-16}} Loughner declined to state his religion in his Army application. In his "Final Thoughts" video, Loughner stated, "No, I don't trust in God!", in reference to the [[United States national motto]] printed on coins and paper currency, "[[In God We Trust]]". He expressed a dislike for all religions, and he was particularly critical of Christians.{{cite web|last=Mozgovaya |first=Natasha |url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/adl-analysis-claims-suspected-arizona-shooter-not-anti-semitic-1.336622 |title=ADL analysis claims suspected Arizona shooter not anti-Semitic – Israel News | Haaretz Daily Newspaper |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=January 12, 2011 |accessdate=August 11, 2012}}The Mindset of Jared Lee Loughner: [https://web.archive.org/web/20110114232701/http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/jared_lee_loughner.htm?Multi_page_sections=sHeading_4 Loughner and Religion], Retrieved August 7, 2012.{{cite web|last=Gibson |first=Dan |url=http://www.tucsonweekly.com/TheRange/archives/2011/01/08/the-crazed-internet-rantings-of-jared-loughner |title=The Crazed Internet Rantings of Jared Loughner |publisher=tucsonweekly.com |date=January 8, 2011 |accessdate=January 23, 2013}} ==Tucson shooting== {{main|2011 Tucson shooting}} [[File:Gabrielle Giffords shooting scene 2.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Roadside sign at the scene the day of the shooting.]] ===Preparation=== Loughner allegedly purchased the 9mm [[Glock pistol]] used in the shooting from a [[Sportsman's Warehouse]] in Tucson on November 30, 2010. The night before the shooting, at 2:05 a.m. he left a message on a friend's [[voicemail]] saying, "Hey man, it's Jared. Me and you had good times. Peace out. Later." In a [[MySpace]] post the morning of the shooting at 4:12 am, he wrote, "Goodbye friends. Please don't be mad at me. The literacy rate is below 5%. I haven't talked to one person who is literate. I want to make it out alive. The longest war in the history of the United States. Goodbye. I'm saddened with the current currency and job employment. I had a bully at school. Thank you. P.S. --[[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|plead the fifth]]!" The MySpace page showed a close-up photo of a handgun sitting atop a document titled "United States History." ===Attack=== On January 8, 2011, at 7:04 a.m. [[Mountain Time Zone|MST]], Loughner went to a [[Walmart]] store near the [[Foothills Mall (Arizona)|Foothills Mall]] to purchase ammunition, but left that store and completed his purchase at Walmart on North Cortaro Road at 7:28 a.m. He was stopped by [[Arizona Game and Fish Department]] officer Alen Edward Forney at 7:34 a.m. for running a red light, but once the officer determined there were no outstanding warrants for Loughner, he was allowed to proceed to his destination with a warning to drive carefully. Loughner took a taxi to a [[Safeway Inc.|Safeway]] supermarket location in [[Casas Adobes, Arizona|Casas Adobes]], where Rep. Giffords was holding a constituents meeting. The shooting occurred at 10:10 a.m. MST. Loughner opened fire on Giffords from close range, hitting her as well as numerous bystanders, and killing six people. Thirteen other people were injured by gunfire, and one person was injured while fleeing the scene of the shooting.{{cite news |last=Bell |first=Melissa |last2=Buck |first2=James |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/blog-post/2011/01/arizona_shooting_victims_the_i.html |title=Updated: List of injured victims in Arizona shooting released by Pima County sheriff |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 14, 2011 |accessdate=January 14, 2011}} Giffords, the apparent target of the attack, was shot in the head and critically injured. ==Arrest and legal proceedings== ===Arrest=== [[File:Jared Loughner sheriff's office.jpg|thumb|upright|This photo of a smiling Loughner, taken by the Pima County Sheriff's Office's forensic unit, saw widespread distribution via media outlets]] Loughner was stopped by bystanders and was arrested by police, saying, "I plead [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|the Fifth]]," as he was taken into custody. A photograph taken by the Pima County Sheriff's Office's forensic unit was released to the media on January 10, 2011{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Dylan |url=http://www.tucsonsentinel.com/local/report/011011_loughner_photo |title=Photo of accused gunman Jared Loughner released |newspaper=Tucson Sentinel |date=January 10, 2011 |accessdate=January 31, 2011}} and published on front pages nationwide. ''[[The Washington Post]]'' described Loughner's expression in the photo as "smirking and creepy, with hollow eyes ablaze," while the art director for ''The New York Times'' said the photo was featured on the front page because it "was the picture of the day [...] it was intense and arresting. It invited you to look and study, and wonder." ===Charges and imprisonment=== Loughner was charged in federal court with one count of attempted [[assassination]] of a member of Congress, two counts of murder of a federal employee (Giffords' aide and Judge Roll), and two counts of attempting to murder a federal employee, based on his injury of two of Giffords' aides. He was [[indictment|indicted]] on three of the charges on January 19, 2011.{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41155912/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/ |title=Grand jury indicts Arizona shooting suspect |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |date=January 19, 2011 |accessdate=January 19, 2011}} Loughner was held without [[bail]] in the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Phoenix|Federal Correctional Institution at Phoenix]], kept isolated from other inmates 23 hours a day and allowed out of his cell for one hour a day to shower and exercise.{{cite news |last=Markon |first=Jerry |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/16/AR2011011604721.html |title=Federal court authorities plan to move trial of Tucson shooting suspect |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=January 17, 2011 |accessdate=January 18, 2011}} On February 24, 2011, he was transferred to the [[United States Penitentiary Tucson|United States Penitentiary in Tucson]]. Attorney [[Judy Clarke]], a former federal [[public defender]] who in the past had represented suspects in several high-profile murder and terrorism cases, was appointed to represent Loughner in federal court. The entire federal judiciary of Arizona recused themselves from hearing the case because of their ties to fellow judge John Roll, who was killed. Federal prosecutors opposed motions to move the case outside of Arizona because of pre-trial publicity. At the direction of [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Appeals court]] [[Alex Kozinski|Chief Judge Kozinski]], the federal case was assigned to [[Larry Alan Burns]], a [[San Diego]]-based judge from the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|Southern District of California]]. Prosecutors representing [[Government of Arizona|the State of Arizona]], which has [[concurrent jurisdiction]] in the matter, announced they intended to file murder and attempted murder charges on behalf of the other victims, those who were not members of Congress or federal employees (although they could legally file charges on behalf of all the victims). Arizona state prosecutors normally have ten days from the time a suspect is brought into custody to file charges, but time spent in federal custody does not count towards this limitation. Arizona law does not permit a verdict of "[[not guilty by reason of insanity]]", but does allow for a verdict of "guilty but insane." ===Initial pleading and additional charges=== On January 24, 2011, Loughner appeared at the [[Sandra Day O'Connor United States Courthouse|Sandra Day O'Connor U.S. Courthouse]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], before Judge Larry Alan Burns from San Diego.{{cite news |last=Bryan|first=Wright |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/01/25/133188453/loughner-pleads-not-guilty |title=Loughner Pleads 'Not Guilty' |publisher=[[National Public Radio]] |date=January 24, 2011 |accessdate=January 29, 2011}} Loughner, whose hair had partially regrown since his arrest, smiled while presented with the charges related to the shooting, including the attempted killing of Giffords and two of her aides. Loughner's attorney, [[Judy Clarke]], requested that Judge Burns select a plea on her client's behalf, to which a plea of not guilty was recorded. When Burns asked Clarke if Loughner understood the charges against him, she replied that they were "not raising that issue" at the time. She did not object to a request by prosecutors to have future hearings moved back to Tucson.{{cite news |last=Riccardi |first=Nicholas |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jan/25/nation/la-na-jared-loughner-20110125 |title=Not guilty plea is entered for Jared Loughner in Tucson attacks |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=January 25, 2011 |accessdate=January 29, 2011}} On March 3, 2011, a federal grand jury indicted Loughner on additional charges of murder and attempted murder for a total of 49 counts.{{Cite news | last=Cratty | first=Carol | url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/03/04/arizona.loughner/ | title=Alleged Tucson gunman indicted on 49 charges in shooting | publisher=CNN | date=March 4, 2011 | accessdate=March 5, 2011}} On March 9, 2011, Loughner pleaded not guilty to all 49 charges.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/jared-loughner-suspected-tucson-arizona-shooter-pleads-not-guilty/story?id=13097807|title=Jared Loughner Pleads Not Guilty to 49 Charges, Including Murder|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=March 9, 2011|accessdate=March 13, 2011}} ===Relationship with lawyers=== On May 25, 2011, Judge Burns stated, "I got some letters declaring some conflict with his counsel...I intend to table them at this time. At such a point that his competency is restored, if he wants to bring up the matter of counsel, he can renew it then."{{cite book|title=court transcript, 2011-May-25|page=52|url=https://docs.google.com/open?id=0B5ZYXb_HdIQhdzhGQVVLQWhXRk0}} The judge suppressed the letters from the court record.{{cite book|title=docket report|url=https://docs.google.com/open?id=0B5ZYXb_HdIQhWDkwbEg0X0tHM1k}} ===Medico-legal proceedings=== On May 25, 2011, Judge Burns ruled Loughner was then incompetent to stand trial, based on two medical evaluations. Court proceedings were suspended while Loughner, who had been [[Diagnosis|diagnosed]] with [[paranoid]] [[schizophrenia]], received [[psychiatric]] treatment at the psychiatric wing of the [[U.S. Medical Center for Federal Prisoners]] in [[Springfield, Missouri]]. He was scheduled to appear in court on September 21, 2011, but that hearing was delayed until September 28, 2011, when the judge reviewed whether he could understand the charges against him and could assist in his own defense. (Loughner's lawyers unsuccessfully objected to him appearing at the hearing.){{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iK2uRKzZF2itfdaFMkAolesKopSA?docId=83bdfd5def024c6f8bb511b99811dc16|title=APNewsbreak: Loughner wants to be at hearing|agency=Associated Press|date=September 21, 2011|accessdate=September 25, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110922201104/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iK2uRKzZF2itfdaFMkAolesKopSA?docId=83bdfd5def024c6f8bb511b99811dc16|archivedate=September 22, 2011}} Loughner disrupted the court hearing with an outburst, and was carried from the court room. According to ''The New York Times'', Loughner believed he succeeded in killing Giffords, and clashed with his lawyer when she informed him that the congresswoman had survived.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/26/us/26loughner.html|title=Suspect in Shooting of Giffords Ruled Unfit for Trial|first=Marc|last=Lacey|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 25, 2011|accessdate=May 26, 2011}} He was judged still incompetent to stand trial following medical evaluations and a hearing in May 2011. ====Forced medication rulings==== On June 26, 2011, Judge Burns ruled that prison doctors could [[Involuntary treatment|forcibly medicate]] Loughner with [[antipsychotic]] drugs in order to treat him to restore him to competency for trial.Graham, Marty (June 29, 2011). [https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/30/us-shooting-loughner-medication-idUSTRE75S85P20110630 Judge rules prison can forcibly medicate Loughner.] [[Reuters]]Perry, Tony (June 30, 2011). [http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-loughner-20110630,0,6329506.story Suspected Tucson gunman can be forced to take antipsychotic drugs, judge rules.] ''Los Angeles Times'' But, on July 12, 2011, a three-judge federal appeals panel from the Ninth Circuit ruled that Loughner could refuse anti-psychotic medication, since he "has not been convicted of a crime, is presumptively innocent and is therefore entitled to greater constitutional protections than a convicted inmate."[http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/general/2011/07/12/11-10339_order.pdf USA v Jared Lee Loughner – Order July 12, 2011] – US Court of Appeals for the Ninth District {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125105321/http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/general/2011/07/12/11-10339_order.pdf |date=January 25, 2012 }}Thompson, Scott (July 13, 2011). [http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/07/13/loughner.forced.medication/index.html Court: Jared Loughner can refuse anti-psychotic medication.] ''[[CNN]]''Emshwiller, John R.; Audi, Tamara (July 12, 2011). [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303678704576442641078371886 Federal Court Sides With Loughner in Drug Debate], ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/07/13/loughner.forced.medication/index.html?hpt=hp_t2|title=Court: Jared Loughner can refuse anti-psychotic medication|publisher=CNN|date=July 13, 2011|accessdate=July 13, 2011}} However, the ruling stated that it "does not preclude prison authorities from taking other measures to maintain the safety of prison personnel, other inmates and Loughner himself, including forced administration of tranquilizers". A week after the ruling, prison medical authorities resumed forcible treatment of Loughner with the antipsychotic [[risperidone]], this time citing ''[[Washington v. Harper]]'' and stating the purpose of treatment was the need to control the danger he posed to himself and others in prison, rather than rendering him fit for trial.[https://web.archive.org/web/20111105171637/http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/general/2011/07/21/11-10339_second_emergency_motion.pdf USA vs Loughner – Defence: Second Emergency Motion July 21, 2011 (p7)] – US Courts for the Ninth District{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/44319262/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/t/doctors-ariz-shooting-suspect-still-not-competent-trial|title=Doctors: Ariz. shooting suspect still not competent for trial|work=msnbc.com|accessdate=September 13, 2014}} Loughner's defense team submitted an emergency motion to the US Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, claiming that this treatment was in violation of their ruling and seeking an immediate injunction to halt treatment. The request for an injunction was denied by the court, allowing treatment to continue pending a full hearing into the matter.[https://web.archive.org/web/20111105173950/http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/general/2011/07/22/11-10339_order_dnyng_emrgnc_mtn.pdf ''USA v Loughner'': Order denying emergency motion for injunctive relief. 13, 2012|accessdate=June 6, 2012|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=June 6, 2012}} ===Guilty plea and sentencing=== {{BLP sources section|date=August 2017}} On August 7, 2012, Judge Burns found Loughner competent to stand trial based on medical evaluations. Loughner pleaded guilty to 19 counts at the hearing, which spared him the death penalty. The hearing began with Loughner listening calmly to testimony from Christina Pietz, Loughner's [[forensic psychologist]], who testified that he had displayed depressive symptoms in 2006 and was formally diagnosed with schizophrenia in 2011. Pietz said that she believed that, after having been forcibly medicated for more than a year, Loughner had expressed remorse and was a changed individual. She said that he was competent to stand trial and agree to a plea.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/accused-tucson-shooter-mentally-fit-pleads-guilty/|title=Accused Tucson shooter mentally fit, pleads guilty|access-date=2017-12-31|language=en}} Sentencing was set for November 15, 2012 at 10 a.m. local time. The sentence could not include the [[death penalty]], because the guilty plea bargain was made with an assurance that it would not be sought; Loughner under the law faced a mandatory sentence of life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/gabrielle-giffords-confronts-shooter-jared-lee-loughner-in-court/2012/11/08/09968fe2-29c7-11e2-b4e0-346287b7e56c_story.html|title=Loughner faces victims in being sentenced to life in prison without parole|last=Ball|first=James|date=2012-11-08|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-12-31|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} Former U.S. Representative Gabrielle Giffords and her husband, retired [[NASA]] astronaut [[Mark Kelly]], U.S. Representative [[Ron Barber]], a former aide to Mrs. Giffords who was shot in the attack, [[U.S. Attorney General]] [[Eric Holder]], and the [[United States District Court for the District of Arizona|U.S. Attorney for Arizona]], [[John S. Leonardo]], had all approved the plea.{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/07/29/gabrielle-giffords-shooter_n_5631597.html|title=Gabrielle Giffords Opposed Death Penalty For Her Shooter|last=Stein|first=Sam|date=2014-07-29|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-12-31|language=en-US}} It was offered and accepted after consultation with them and with the families of the other victims. By pleading guilty in the deal, Loughner automatically waived his right to any further appeals and [[Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure|cannot later alter his plea to an insanity plea]].{{cite web |title= Rule 11. Pleas {{!}} Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure |url= https://www.law.cornell.edu/rules/frcrmp/rule_11|accessdate=October 2, 2017}} Loughner must pay a [[restitution]] of $19 million, $1 million for each of the victims. He [[Civil asset forfeiture|forfeited the weapons he used in the incident]], and [[Son of Sam law#Lawsuits|any money earned from efforts to sell his story.]] Loughner calmly answered that he understood each charge, and signed his initials after each page of the agreement and shakily signed his name to it, dated August 6.{{cite web|title=Jared Loughner is found competent to stand trial|url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/20120807tucson-shooting-loughner-court-hearing.html#ixzz22tHjm9PP|work=Arizona Republic|accessdate=August 7, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/08/07/13163448-jared-loughner-pleads-guilty-to-tucson-shootings-avoids-death-penalty?lite|title=Jared Loughner pleads guilty to Tucson shootings, avoids death penalty – U.S. News|publisher=NBC News|date=August 7, 2012|accessdate=August 11, 2012}} On November 8, 2012, Loughner appeared in front of [[U.S. District Court]] Judge [[Larry Alan Burns]] in a court in [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]]. He was sentenced to serve seven consecutive life terms plus 140 years in prison [[Sentencing Act of 1987|without parole.]]{{cite web|title=Loughner sentenced to life in prison without parole|date=November 8, 2012|url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2012/11/08/victims-enter-court-for-giffords-shooter-sentencing/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 8, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Ball|first=James|title=Jared Lee Loughner sentenced to life in prison|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/gabrielle-giffords-confronts-shooter-jared-lee-loughner-in-court/2012/11/08/09968fe2-29c7-11e2-b4e0-346287b7e56c_story.html|accessdate=November 14, 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=November 8, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Duke|first=Alan|title=Loughner sentenced to life for Arizona shootings|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/11/08/justice/arizona-loughner-sentencing/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 14, 2012|date=November 9, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Santos|first=Fernanda|title=Gunman in Giffords Shooting Sentenced to 7 Life Terms|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/09/us/gunman-who-shot-giffords-to-be-sentenced.html?ref=jaredleeloughner&_r=0|accessdate=November 14, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 8, 2012}} Even though he was convicted and sentenced in federal court, there was still a possibility that Loughner could be tried for murder and other crimes in [[Arizona]] court. Pima County Attorney Barbara LaWall declared later that afternoon that she would not prosecute Jared Loughner on behalf of the State of Arizona. LaWall explained that her decision would afford the victims and their families, as well as the community in Tucson and Pima County, an opportunity to move forward with their lives. She said that, after speaking and consulting personally with each of the surviving victims and with the family members of those killed, it was clear that they would not be benefitted by a State prosecution. Surviving victims and family members told LaWall that they are "completely satisfied with the federal prosecution", that "justice has been served", and that the federal sentence is "suitably severe".{{cite web |url=http://www.tucsonlocalmedia.com/news/article_f396fab0-29f3-11e2-9ec5-001a4bcf887a.html |title=Pima County Attorney won't prosecute Loughner - The Explorer: News |work=The Explorer |accessdate=September 13, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZpFstUz6?url=http://www.tucsonlocalmedia.com/news/article_f396fab0-29f3-11e2-9ec5-001a4bcf887a.html |archivedate=July 6, 2015 |df= }} () Loughner is currently serving his life sentence at the [[Federal Medical Center, Rochester]], [[Minnesota]], a prison for inmates with specialized health issues.{{cite news|last1=Simmons|first1=Taj|title=Rochester Federal Medical Center marks 30th anniversary|url=http://www.kttc.com/story/30137129/2015/09/29/rochester-federal-medical-center-marks-30th-anniversary|accessdate=24 December 2015|publisher=Frankly Media and KTTC|date=September 29, 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em | refs = {{cite news | author = CNN Wire Staff | title = Loughner's dad feared he was 'out of control,' neighbor says | date = January 13, 2011 | work = CNN | accessdate =January 13, 2011 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/01/12/arizona.shooting.suspect/ }} {{cite news | last = Quinones | first = Sam | title = Jared Lee Loughner's parents alone with their anguish, neighbor says | date = January 10, 2011 | newspaper = Los Angeles Times | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-0111-loughner-parents-20110111,0,4724244.story | accessdate =January 11, 2011 }} {{cite news | last = Jacob | first = Jijo | title = Who is Jared Lee Loughner? '''Joe Schriner''' (born March 3, 1955) is an [[Americans|American]] [[political activist]] and journalist. Schriner has run for [[President of the United States|the United States presidency]] in five consecutive election cycles spanning from 2000 to 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.starbeacon.com/archives/in-the-presidential-campaign-it-was-joe-the-plumber-in/article_83ec78a2-367c-54b6-852b-4c1e6bd8d3c2.html|title = In the 2008 presidential campaign it was Joe the Plumber. In 2012 it’s going to be Joe the Painter.|date = January 14, 2009|accessdate = September 15, 2015|publisher = Star Beacon}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/#!declaration-speech/c45p|title = Schriner 2016 declaration speech podcast|date = September 12, 2015|accessdate = September 15, 2015|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> He has primarily run as an [[Independent politician|independent candidate]], but he also ran as a [[Republican presidential candidates|Republican]] during the early portions of the 2010 and 2016 presidential election cycles.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/2000/0208/p3s1.html|title = A van, a message, and a mission |date = February 8, 2000|accessdate = September 15, 2015|publisher = Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> He also vied unsuccessfully for the [[Green Party of the United States|Green Party]] presidential nomination during the 2008 election cycle.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yWCxuUp8pw4|title = Green Party Presidential Candidate Forum talk, Reading, PA.|date = July 2007|accessdate = October 14, 2016}}</ref>
Before becoming a [[perennial candidate]], Schriner spent a significant amount of time travelling across the United States and conducting ad hoc interviews with individuals he met. Schriner purports that these subjective experiences leave him better-informed about national social, political, and economic issues than experienced policymakers. He has been interviewed by numerous media outlets over the years and has spoken at various colleges and universities.<ref name="College Talks">{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/college-talks|title = College Talks|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref>
Schriner has been billed as "average Joe" in the media.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.nptelegraph.com/average-joe-runs-for-president/article_d217148f-d741-5f12-8363-e967d20b698b.html|title = "Average Joe" Runs for President |date = May 25, 2004|accessdate = September 12, 2015|publisher = The North Platte Telegraph}}</ref> He is also sometimes referred to as "Joe the Painter."<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Joseph-Schriner/840536|title = Joe the painter running for president |date = March 5, 2010|accessdate = September 12, 2015|publisher = LaGrange Daily News}}</ref> He is currently self-employed as a [[House painter and decorator|house painter]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/#!making-a-living/c17zs|title = Making a Living |date = September 12, 2015|accessdate = September 12, 2015|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> In addition, he is a [[Freelancer|free-lance writer]] for his hometown newspaper, ''The Bluffton News''.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.blufftonnews.com/node?page=1|title = Bluffton News (pen name: "Average Joe") multiple stories|date = September 17, 2005|accessdate = September 12, 2015}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Joe Schriner was born on March 3, 1955, in [[Cleveland|Cleveland, Ohio]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://enc.slider.com/Enc/Joe_Schriner |title=Slider on Joseph Charles Schriner |date=2008 |accessdate=September 20, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141028170300/http://enc.slider.com/Enc/Joe_Schriner |archivedate=October 28, 2014 |df= }}</ref> In 1973, he graduated from Bay Village High School, where he was the starting quarterback on the [[Football team|junior varsity football team]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/#!joe-the-qb/c1stc|title = Joe the Quarterback|date = September 12, 2015|accessdate = September 20, 2015|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref>
Schriner spent his freshman year at [[Bluffton University|Bluffton College]] in [[Ohio]]. After taking a year off from school to work, he transferred to [[Bowling Green State University]]. He majored in journalism, wrote for the [[Student newspaper|college newspaper]], and completed an [[internship]] as a [[Journalist|reporter]] on Ohio’s ''[[Troy Daily News]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/on-the-street|title = Troy Daily News article, 1977|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> Schriner earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[journalism]] from Bowling Green State University in 1978.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bgfalconmedia.com/university-alumnus-runs-for-united-states-president/article_e4fae654-4368-523e-bbf3-a4859a70ab51.html|title = University alumnus runs for United States President |date = September 23, 2003|accessdate = October 14, 2016|publisher = BG News}}</ref>
== Early career == Schriner began his career as a [[Journalism|journalist]] after college for the ''[[Sandusky Register]]''. He was assigned as a bureau [[Journalist|reporter]] to cover [[Huron, Ohio]]. He wrote about the town government and issues facing the local school division, in addition to various human interest features. Schriner left the ''Register'' after two years.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/local-gov|title = Sandusky Register (Huron Bureau) article, 1978|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref>
Schriner then became a reporter for a new publication in [[Lorain, Ohio]] called ''The Metropolitan''. However, the publication was dissolved after eight months.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/black-issues|title = The Metropolitan News (Toni Morrison article), 1982|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref>
In 1983, Schriner began working at a halfway house in [[Lorain, Ohio|Lorain]] as a [[mental health counselor|drug and alcoholism counselor]]. The halfway house was a 90-day treatment program run operated by the Lorain County Council on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse (LCCADA). During the next two years, Schriner pursued seminar studies to become a certified drug and alcoholism counselor.<ref name=counselor>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/joe-the-counselor|title = Lorain County Council on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse newsletter article, addendum note, 1985|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> After receiving this certification, he became an [[outpatient]] counselor (also with LCCADA), specializing in both individual and group counseling. Schriner eventually developed one of the first outpatient treatment models in the Midwest for "[[adult children of alcoholics]]".<ref name=counselor /> He later went into private practice in [[Cleveland]], specializing in [[Addiction|drug addiction]], [[alcoholism]], and [[Family therapy|addictive family system dynamics]] in the late 1980s.
== Cross country research == In 1990, Schriner phased out his private [[Counseling psychology|counseling]] practice and took to the roads of [[United States|America]] to begin extensive cross country research that would eventually lead to him running for president. He traveled some 100,000 miles from 1990 to 1998 interviewing people about a wide variety of issues. Information from these interviews would then be plugged into extensive position papers.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/joes-cross-country-research|title = Cross Country Travels audio and text|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref>
During this time, he also became a "lay [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] speaker" talking in numerous churches throughout the country about such topics as: [[abortion]]; [[euthanasia]]; the [[Poverty|poor]]; [[environmental stewardship]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/joe-as-a-lay-catholic-speaker|title = Joe as a Lay Catholic Speaker|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> (He believes in a [[Consistent life ethic|Consistent Life Ethic]] and a good deal of his political platform revolves around the precepts of [[Catholic social teaching|Catholic Social Teaching]].)<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.catholic.org/news/politics/story.php?id=28528|title = Catholic Online, Editorial: Not your Average Joe. Maybe I Will Vote for Joe Schriner?|date = July 10, 2008|accessdate = September 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/catholic-president|title = Article reprints: Agua Viva newspaper (Las Cruces, New Mexico, Catholic Diocese), Universe Bulletin (Cleveland, Ohio, Catholic Diocese); articles appeared during Campaign 2004|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref>
== Presidential campaigns == ===2000=== Schriner declared to run for [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] the first time with a speech at the [[Liberty Bell]] in [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, PA]], on April 30, 1999.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/e98/bios/president/main2.htm|title = Campaign 2000 candidate Party listings|accessdate = September 20, 2015|publisher = ''USA Today''}}</ref> He initially declared as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidate, but then switched to [[Independent politician|independent]] after [[George W. Bush]] won the [[Republican Party presidential primaries|Republican Primaries]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = |title = Independent Presidential Candidate Supports Radical Change (The Digital Universe / Brigham Young University) |date = October 12, 2000 |access-date = }}</ref> During that campaign, Schriner and his family were on the road 19 continuous months and traveled 20,000 campaign miles.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/2000|title = Campaign Tours 2000|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> The family did a number of what they referred to as Americana Tour Routes: [[U.S. Route 66 in New Mexico|Old Route 66]]; the [[Old National Pike Milestones|Old National Pike]]; the [[Lewis and Clark Trail|Lewis & Clark Trail]], to name a few.<ref name=":0" /> For this campaign, they also did a 2,000-mile Back-to-Basics Tour through the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]] on bicycles.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=110&dat=20000719&id=pDZQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3FUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6938,1777490&hl=en|title = Average Joe rides for president (The Luddington News)|date = July 19, 2000|accessdate = September 20, 2015}}</ref> His travels for this campaign are chronicled in the book: ''Back Road to the White House''.
===2004=== Schriner ran again in 2004,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cadillacnews.com/news_story/?story_id=6840&year=2003&issue=20030616|title = Average Joe makes White House Bid |date = June 16, 2003|accessdate = September 20, 2015|publisher = Cadillac News}}</ref> with him and his family logging some 40,000 campaign miles.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/2004|title = Tours of 2004 |accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> They, again, did tours with Americana themes: the Country Music Highway; the "Black Belt Region" Tour; a "Coast-to-Coast" Tour. In addition, the Schriners campaigned heavily in [[Ohio]] this election, including a 1,300-mile [[Buckeye State|Buckeye]] Trail Tour.<ref name=tour>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/tour-maps-cgl0|title = Joe’s Campaign Tour Overview|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> A hallmark of the campaign is doing regular, and impromptu, "back road stumping" on small town street corners, in diners and in village parks.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/stumping|title = Stumping |accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> In addition, during this time he talked at the [[University of Dayton]], the [[University of Toledo]], and [[Greenville College]].<ref name="College Talks"/>
===2008 and 2012=== During these two campaigns, the Schriner family accumulatively traveled some 50,000 miles.<ref name=tour /> Besides the small town stumping, during this time Schriner also talked at [[Holy Cross College (Indiana)|Holy Cross College]], the [[University of Notre Dame]], [[LaGrange College]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=University of Notre Dame Center for Social Concerns Talk Archive, this talk on: January 27, 2010 |url= http://www3.nd.edu/~socconcn//about/Archives.shtml |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925121642/http://www3.nd.edu/~socconcn//about/Archives.shtml |archivedate=September 25, 2015 |df= }}</ref> The family also did an extended "[[Immigration to the United States|Immigration]] [[Border]] Tour" looking at [[Immigration to the United States|Hispanic Immigration]] issues, as they traveled the [[San Joaquin Valley]] looking at [[Farmworker|farm worker]] issues.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/2006|title = Joe Tour Maps, 2006|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> During part of these campaigns, the Schriners also moved to a hardscrabble area of [[Cleveland|Cleveland, Ohio]] (just west of the inner city) to do outreach work with the [[Catholic Worker Movement|Catholic Workers]] there.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/joe-the-volunteer|title = Joe the Volunteer |accessdate = October 14, 2016 |website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> In between campaign tours, the Schriners lived in [[Cleveland]] for five years. Schriner wrote the book ''America’s Best Urban Neighborhood'' about the family’s experiences in Cleveland. After the Cleveland experience, the Schriners moved back to [[Bluffton, Ohio|Bluffton]] in 2011. Schriner has also written two books about Bluffton: ''America’s Best Town'' and ''America’s Best Town 2''. He writes that Bluffton has the "best quality of life" when it comes to such things as town [[Comrade|camaraderie]], [[Activism|civic activism]], [[outreach]] to the [[Poverty|poor]], [[environmental stewardship]], and downtown vibrancy. These are all qualities that he emphasizes in his [[Party platform|political platform]].<ref name=positions>{{Cite web|url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/positions-ci8x|title = Joe’s positions|accessdate = October 14, 2016|website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref>
=== 2016 === In keeping with the [[Grassroots democracy|grassroots]] nature of Schriner’s campaign, he initially put up a campaign flier on a general store bulletin board in [[Beaverdam, Ohio]], in October 2014. Schriner subsequently declared his candidacy in a [[podcast]] on the home page of his official campaign [[website]].<ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/declaration-speech |title = 2016 Declaration Speech by Joe Schriner |accessdate = October 14, 2016 |website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> This marks his fifth consecutive run for president.<ref>{{Cite web |url = https://www.npr.org/2011/09/23/140701113/also-rans-what-drives-the-perennial-candidates |title = Also-Rans: What Drives The Perennial Candidates? |date = September 23, 2011 |accessdate = October 14, 2016 |publisher = NPR}}</ref>
Schriner, a [[Journalism|journalist]], has traveled the country extensively, interviewing a wide variety of people for a comprehensive series of lengthy position papers on many topics of the day.<ref name="positions"/> The lynchpin of his campaign revolves around a "[[Consistent life ethic|Consistent Life Ethic]]" that sets him against [[abortion]], [[euthanasia]], [[poverty]], [[global warming]], [[nuclear proliferation]], [[violence]] on the streets and anything else that can end life prematurely.<ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/life-issues |title = Life Issues |accessdate = October 14, 2016 |website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> Schriner was one of the featured speakers at the Consistent Life 25th Anniversary Conference in [[Chevy Chase, Maryland]] (March 9–11, 2012).<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.consistent-life.org/confschedule.pdf |title = Consistent Life 25th Anniversary syllabus |accessdate = October 14, 2016}}</ref> Schriner has also repeatedly said that he and his wife Liz are running as "concerned parents" from the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]].<ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.myplainview.com/news/article_f3bcbd9a-6b8c-11df-87d6-001cc4c002e0.html |title = Presidential Candidate Makes Stop in Plainview |date = May 29, 2010 |accessdate = October 14, 2016 |publisher = Plainview Daily Herald}}</ref>
Shortly before the 2016 election Schriner and his family moved to Steubenville, Ohio.<ref name=nbcnews/>
==Personal life== Schriner resides in [[Steubenville, Ohio]].<ref name=nbcnews>{{cite web | url = http://voteforjoeblog.com/?p=1584 | title = NBC News, Wired, house painting, stumping, voting… Jonathan’s question | date = November 9, 2016 | accessdate = November 9, 2016 | publisher = VoteForJoe.com }}</ref> He and his wife Liz have three children.<ref name=family>{{Cite web |url = http://www.voteforjoe.com/first-family |title = About Family |accessdate = October 14, 2016 |website = www.voteforjoe.com}}</ref> Schriner met his wife, a native of [[New Zealand]], on the road in [[Homer, Alaska]].<ref name=family /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.post-journal.com/page/content.detail/id/537541.html?nav=5057 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715105857/http://www.post-journal.com/page/content.detail/id/537541.html?nav=5057 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 15, 2011 |title=Not Your 'Average Joe' |date=August 14, 2009 |accessdate=October 14, 2016 |publisher=The Post-Journal }}</ref>

{{slavery}} '''Joseph Antonio Emidy''' (1775 – 23 April 1835) was a [[Guinea]]-born musician who was [[slavery|enslaved]] in early life, before becoming a notable and celebrated [[violin]]ist and [[composer]] in [[Cornwall]], [[South-West England]]. ==Life== Born in [[Guinea]], Emidy was sold into slavery as a child to [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] [[Merchant|traders]] who took him to [[Brazil]] and later to [[Portugal]]. In Portugal, he became a [[virtuoso]] violinist in the Lisbon [[Opera]]. He was [[Impressment|press-ganged]] by British [[Admiral]] Sir [[Edward Pellew]] during the [[Napoleonic wars]] and spent the next four years as a ship's [[fiddler]].{{cite web |url= http://www.janeausten.co.uk/admiral-edward-pellew-the-true-history-of-this-most-novel-captain/ |title=Admiral Edward Pellew: The true history of this most novel Captain - Jane Austen Centre |first=Laura|last=Boyle |work=janeausten.co.uk |year=2013 |quote= |accessdate=29 May 2013}} ==Music== [[File:Joseph Antonio Emidy.jpg|thumb|left|Early 19th-century sketch of the Truro Philharmonic Orchestra with Joseph Antonio Emidy]] In 1799, Emidy was abandoned in [[Falmouth, Cornwall|Falmouth]], [[Cornwall]], [[United Kingdom]]. In Falmouth, he earned his living as a violinist and a [[teacher]]. He became the leader of the Truro [[Philharmonic Orchestra]], and went on to become one of the most celebrated and influential musical figures in early 19th-century Cornwall. He composed many works, including concertos and a symphony, but no known copies survive.[http://www.balh.co.uk/lhn/article.php?file=lhn-vol1iss83-6.xml Cornwall, musicians, history] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111224310/http://www.balh.co.uk/lhn/article.php?file=lhn-vol1iss83-6.xml |date=11 November 2007 }} (British Association for Local History). ==Personal life== In 1802, he married Jane Hutchins, a local tradesman’s daughter,{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=5uze6D-uSugC&pg=PA47 |title=Black Salt: Seafarers of African Descent on British Ships |first=Ray|last=Costello |publisher=Liverpool University Press |year=2012 |accessdate=29 May 2013}} and they had eight children. They moved to [[Truro]] around 1815. ==Death== [[File:DSCN1660EmidyGrave.jpg|thumb|150px|right|Gravestone of Joseph Antonio Emidy in Kenwyn Churchyard]] He died in [[Truro]], Cornwall, and his grave is in [[Kenwyn]] churchyard. Transcript of his gravestone reads:
HERE LIE DEPOSITED The mortal remains of Mr Jos:h Antonia Emidy Who departed this life, On the 23:rd of April 1835 AGED 60 YEARS
And sacred to whose memory This tribute of affection is erected By his surviving family. He was native of PORTUGAL Which country he quit about forty years since and pursuing the Musical Profession, resided in Cornwall until the close of his earthly career. Devoted to thy soul-inspiring strains, Sweet Music! Thee he hail'd his chief delight And with fond zeal that shunn'd nor toil nor pain His talent sear'd, and genius mark'd its flight In harmony he liv'd, in peace with all Took his departure from this world of woe, And here his rest, till the last Trumpet's call, Shall 'wake mankind to joys that endless flow.
==Tributes== On 24 March 2007, during a service at Kenwyn Church to mark the 200th anniversary of the [[Slave Trade Act 1807|parliamentary abolition of the slave trade]] throughout the [[British Empire]], the life of Emidy was featured and some typical pieces of music from his time were played in tribute. Emidy is the subject of a play by Dr [[Alan M. Kent]], ''The Tin Violin''.{{cite web |url=http://bishbashboshproductions.co.uk/work/the-tin-violin-2012/ |title=The Tin Violin 2012 | Bish Bash Bosh Productions |first=Alan |last=Kent |work=bishbashboshproductions.co.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=29 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130718155628/http://bishbashboshproductions.co.uk/work/the-tin-violin-2012/ |archivedate=18 July 2013 |df= }} In 2015 a carved wooden boss was erected in [[Truro Cathedral]] in his memory.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cornwall-33211440|title=Joseph Emidy: From slave fiddler to classical violinist|author=Miles Davis|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=21 June 2015|accessdate=23 June 2015}} ==See also== * [[Samuel Coleridge-Taylor]] another black English composer (1875-1912) ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== * He is mentioned at length (pp. 163–172) in the autobiography of [[James Silk Buckingham]] (MP for Sheffield), which was published in 1855. *[-?-] "My Hero Joseph Emidy", ''BBC History'' magazine, October 2001 * Richard McGrady, ''Music and Musicians in Early Nineteenth Century Cornwall: the world of Joseph Emidy - slave, violinist and composer''. Exeter: Exeter University Press, 1991, {{ISBN|0-85989-359-6}} * Richard McGrady, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/69885 "Emidy, Joseph Antonio (c.1770–1835)"], ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', [[Oxford University Press]], 2004; accessed 11 October 2007. ==External links== *[http://www.emidy.com/home Official homepage] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cornwall/6464121.stm Trail marks abolition anniversary (BBC News Story)] *[http://www.jonroseweb.com/f_projects_emidy.html The Emidy Violin Concerto] A Project from Jon Rose. Accessed June 2008 {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Emidy, Joseph Antonio}} [[Category:1775 births]] [[Category:1835 deaths]] [[Category:Brazilian slaves]] [[Category:English classical composers]] [[Category:English male classical composers]] [[Category:Cornish people]] [[Category:Black British former slaves]] [[Category:Black British classical musicians]] [[Category:Portuguese classical violinists]] [[Category:Male violinists]] [[Category:Portuguese emigrants to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Guinean emigrants to England]] [[Category:Burials in Cornwall]]

{{Infobox person | name = Khalid Abdul Muhammad | birth_name = Harold Moore Jr. | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1948|1|12}} | birth_place = [[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2001|2|17|1948|1|12|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], United States | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | alma_mater = [[Pepperdine University]] | occupation = Activist | other_names = | relations = | spouse = }} '''Khalid Abdul Muhammad''' (born '''Harold Moore Jr.'''; January 12, 1948 – February 17, 2001) was an American [[black nationalist]] who came to prominence as a leader in the [[Nation of Islam]] and then the [[New Black Panther Party]]. After a racially inflammatory 1993 speech at [[Kean College]], Muhammad was condemned and removed from his position in the Nation of Islam by [[Louis Farrakhan]]. He was also censured by both Houses of the [[United States Congress]].{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/02/18/nyregion/ka-muhammad-53-dies-ex-official-of-nation-of-islam.html?ref=khalidabdulmuhammad | work=The New York Times | first=Jayson | last=Blair | title=K.A. Muhammad, 53, Dies; Ex-Official of Nation of Islam | date=February 18, 2001}} After being removed from the Nation of Islam he served as the National Chairman of the [[New Black Panther Party]] until his death in 2001 from a [[brain aneurysm]]. Despite the controversy that followed him, his strong and unapologetic denunciations of [[white supremacy]] gained him the support of some in the black community. == Early life == Harold Moore Jr. was raised by his aunt, Carrie Moore Vann, in [[Houston, Texas]], where he attended Bruce Elementary School, E.O. Smith Junior High School, and all-black Phyllis Wheatley High School. After graduating high school, Moore went to [[Dillard University]] in [[Louisiana]], where he was known as Harold Vann, to pursue a degree in theological studies, but he did not graduate. At this time, he ministered at Sloan Memorial Methodist Church. In 1967, he was initiated into [[Omega Psi Phi]] fraternity (Theta Sigma chapter). Later, Moore transferred to [[Pepperdine University]] and earned his [[bachelor's degree]]. ==Nation of Islam== In 1970, while attending Dillard, Moore joined the Nation of Islam,{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Chart: Nation of Islam and Traditional Islam | work = | publisher = Beliefnet | url = http://www.beliefnet.com/Faiths/2002/10/Chart-Nation-of-Islam-and-Traditional-Islam.aspx | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-12-31}} which was then under the leadership of [[Elijah Muhammad]]. He changed his name to Harold Smith or Harold X, then to Malik Rushaddin, became Minister [[Louis Farrakhan]]'s protégé, and was active as a recruiter within the organization. In 1978, Rushaddin was appointed Western Regional Minister of the Nation of Islam and leader of Mosque #27. In 1983, Minister Farrakhan named him Khalid after the Islamic general [[Khalid ibn al-Walid]], a follower of the prophet Muhammad, calling him the Sword of Allah. By 1984, Muhammad had become one of Louis Farrakhan's most trusted advisors in the Nation of Islam. He traveled to Libya on a fund-raising trip, where he became well acquainted with that country's leader, [[Muammar al-Gaddafi]]. Muhammad's dedication to Farrakhan and to the message of the NOI eventually secured him the title of national spokesman and he was named one of Louis Farrakhan's friends in 1981. He served at Nation of Islam mosques in New York and Atlanta throughout the 1980s. A federal court convicted him in 1987 of mortgage fraud and sentenced him to nine months in prison.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/113381 |title=The Itinerant Incendiary |last=Smith |first=Vern E. |author2=Sarah Van Boven |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=September 14, 1998 |accessdate=July 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220154304/http://www.newsweek.com/id/113381 |archivedate=February 20, 2010 }} After his prison term he returned to the Nation, becoming Farrakhan's national advisor in 1991. ===1993 speech=== In 1993, Muhammad gave a speech at [[Kean College]] in [[Union Township, Union County, New Jersey|Union Township, New Jersey]], in which Muhammad referred to Jews as "bloodsuckers", labeled [[Pope John Paul II|the Pope]] a "no-good [[cracker (pejorative)|cracker]]", and advocated the murder of any and all white South Africans who would not leave the nation subsequent to a warning period of 24 hours.{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-02-18/news/0102180453_1_mr-muhammad-james-muhammad-minister-louis-farrakhan |title=Khalid Abdul Muhammad, 53, Fiery Ex-Aide for Farrakhan |first1=James |last1=Janega |first2=Noah |last2=Isackson |date=February 18, 2001 |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |accessdate=November 12, 2017 }}{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/2001/02/18/khalid-muhammad-dies-at-53/ac0d1a96-b2d0-4a80-a1af-cee4c7c5f0e0/ |title=Khalid Muhammad Dies at 53 |date=February 18, 2001 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=November 12, 2017 }} He used the [[Book of John]] in the Bible to defend his statements against "so-called White Jews", saying that they crucified Jesus because he revealed them to be liars, and against "their father, the Devil".{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} The [[United States Senate]] voted 97–0 to censure Muhammad, and the [[United States House of Representatives]] in a special session passed a House Resolution. Farrakhan responded by publicly condemning Muhammad's speech. ==Aftermath== Muhammad was silenced as a minister and left the NOI soon afterward. In 1994, Muhammad [http://video.google.com/videosearch?q=khallid+muhammad appeared on ''The Phil Donahue Show'']. He participated in heated arguments with Jewish audience members amid an explanation of his public statements. Muhammad was shot by James Bess, a former NOI member, after he spoke at the [[University of California, Riverside]] on May 29, 1994. He survived the shooting. Many believed the shooting was a part of a conspiracy against Muhammad.{{cite AV media|people=Cokely, Steve; Muhammad, Khalid |title=Shooting of Khalid Muhammad, Tupac & Biggie 6/6 |trans-title=|medium=YouTube |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_bpxbVxGdg&list=PLu3dHyvwbV6-7H1XeYhzTuNvCj6dehW2G |accessdate=April 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140623071638/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_bpxbVxGdg&list=PLu3dHyvwbV6-7H1XeYhzTuNvCj6dehW2G |archivedate=June 23, 2014 |df= }} ==New Black Panther Party== After being stripped of his position as NOI spokesman, Muhammad became the national chairman of the [[New Black Panther Party]]. On May 21, 1997, he delivered a heated speech at [[San Francisco State University]] in which he criticized Jews, whites, Catholics and homosexuals. In 1998, Muhammad organized the "Million Youth March" in [[New York City]] which attracted an estimated 6,000 participants. The march was controversial from its inception as New York mayor [[Rudolph Giuliani]] denied the organizers a permit, calling it a hate march. A court ruled that the event could go on but scaled back its duration and size. At the conclusion of the rally, just as Muhammad appeared on the stage to speak, the demonstration was interrupted by a low-flying police helicopter. Muhammad alleges that was the signal for more than 3,000 police in riot gear, including some mounted on horseback, to come in and disperse the crowd. In response, Muhammad exhorted the rally participants to attack the oncoming police, to beat them with rails, and to shoot them with their own guns. Dozens were arrested, and 30 officers and five civilians were injured.{{cite web|url=http://samsloan.com/ap-mill.htm |title=Million Youth March Ends in Clash |accessdate=2009-05-07 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020429053930/http://samsloan.com/ap-mill.htm |archivedate=2002-04-29 |df= }}{{cite web|title=The Hunt for Khallid Abdul Muhammad|date=October 13, 1998|author=Noel, Peter|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/news/the-hunt-for-khallid-abdul-muhammad-6423386|work=[[The Village Voice]]}} Mayor Giuliani said that the march turned out to be precisely what he predicted, "filled with hatred, horrible, awful, vicious, anti-Semitic and other anti-white rhetoric, as well as exhortations to kill people, murder people ... the speeches given today should not occur [at] any place." In subsequent activism, Muhammad convened a second march in 1999. In 2000, Muhammad's beliefs were introduced to a completely new demographic when it was revealed that one of the contestants on the [[United States|American]] version of the Dutch television show ''[[Big Brother (U.S.)|Big Brother]]'', William Collins (Hiram Ashantee), was a follower of his. He also appeared in an episode of ''[[Louis Theroux's Weird Weekends]]''. In 2001, Muhammad died suddenly of a [[brain aneurysm]] in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], at the age of 53. He was buried in [[Ferncliff Cemetery]] in [[Westchester County, New York]], near the grave of [[Malcolm X]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/khalid-buried-malcolm-x-article-1.910498 |title=Khalid Buried Near Malcolm X |first=Michael O. |last=Allen |date=February 25, 2001 |work=[[New York Daily News]] |accessdate=December 22, 2016 }} == Musical influence == As a prominent [[Afrocentrist]] and speaker on African history, Muhammad attracted interest from several hip-hop artists, who sampled him in their songs. [[Public Enemy (band)|Public Enemy]] quoted him in the introduction of its 1988 track "Night of the Living Baseheads," from the album ''[[It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back]]'':
Have you forgotten that once we were brought here, we were robbed of our name, robbed of our language. We lost our religion, our culture, our god ... and many of us, by the way we act, we even lost our minds.
[[Rage Against the Machine]] later paraphrased this quote in the lyrics of "Freedom" (''Rage Against the Machine'', 1992) with the line, "Brotha, did you forget your name?" He also appeared on [[Ice Cube]]'s albums ''[[Death Certificate (album)|Death Certificate]]'' (1991) and ''[[Lethal Injection (album)|Lethal Injection]]'' (1993) as a guest rapper. On the former album, Muhammad appeared in the tracks "Death" and "The Birth". On the latter, he appeared in the song "Cave Bitch," a song ridiculing white women. On [[MC Ren]]'s 1996 album ''[[The Villain in Black]]'' Muhammad appeared in the track "Muhammad Speaks," where he spoke about the history of the rights of [[African-Americans]]. Musical references to Muhammad since his death include a quote of his "Kill the White Man" speech on [[The Used]]'s 2009 album ''[[Artwork (album)|Artwork]]'', a sample of his interview with Louis Theroux in the [[Chase & Status]] song "Hocus Pocus", and excerpts from a recording of one of his speeches concerning Jesus in the [[D'Angelo]] song "1000 Deaths" on the 2014 album ''[[Black Messiah (album)|Black Messiah]]''.{{cite web|title=Remembering Dr. Khalid Muhammad: 5 Musical References You Probably Didn't Know|date=October 13, 1998|author=Shae Be Allah|url=http://thesource.com/2015/01/12/remembering-dr-khalid-muhammad-5-musical-references-you-probably-didnt-know/|work=The Source}} ==Personal life== Muhammad had five children, including [[Farrah Gray]], who grew up in [[Chicago's South Side]] without their father present. Although Gray saw his father only during occasional visits, he credits Muhammad for inspiring him with confidence. Gray rose from poverty to become a successful business entrepreneur, but did not join his father's political activities.Gray, Farrah (2012-11-11) [http://www.prlog.org/12020883-farrah-gray-talks-about-his-relationship-with-his-father-khallid-muhammad.html Press release]Gray, Farrah (2004) ''Reallionaire'' == See also == *[[African American–Jewish relations]] *[[Black separatism]] *[[Nation of Islam and antisemitism]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{wikiquote}} *[https://www.adl.org/news/article/khalid-abdul-muhammad-in-his-own-words Khallid Abdul Muhammad: In His Own Words] *[https://www.villagevoice.com/1998/10/13/the-hunt-for-khallid-abdul-muhammad The Hunt for Khalid Abdul Muhammed] *[http://www.thetalkingdrum.com/khallid.html The Bio Of Khallid Abdul Muhammad] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Muhammad, Khalid Abdul}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:2001 deaths]] [[Category:African-American people]] [[Category:Activists for African-American civil rights]] [[Category:Afrocentrists]] [[Category:American Holocaust deniers]] [[Category:American people convicted of fraud]] [[Category:Converts to Islam]] [[Category:Dillard University alumni]] [[Category:Eagle Scouts]] [[Category:Members of the Nation of Islam]] [[Category:People from Houston]] [[Category:Pepperdine University alumni]] [[Category:Deaths from intracranial aneurysm]] [[Category:Journalists from Texas]] [[Category:Anti-white racism in the United States]] [[Category:Anti-Catholicism in the United States]] [[Category:Racism in the United States]] [[Category:Activists from Texas]] [[Category:Burials at Ferncliff Cemetery]] [[Category:American members of the clergy with criminal convictions]]

'''Lior Shambadal''' (1950 in [[Tel Aviv]]) is an [[Israelis|Israeli]] composer and conductor. [[File:Shambadal.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Lior Shambadal image.|Lior Shambadal]]
== Study == Lior Shambadal studied [[viola]], [[trombone]] and conducting in his native city of Tel Aviv. He studied theory and composition with [[Sergiu Natra]]. His studies led him to [[Carles Melles]] at the Salzburg Mozarteum, as well as to [[Hans Swarowsky]] in [[Vienna]], and to conducting studies with [[Carlo Maria Giulini]], [[Igor Markevitch]], [[Sergiu Celibidache]] and [[Franco Ferrara]]. He continued his education with, inter alia, [[Electronic Music]] in Vienna and composition in [[France]] with [[Witold Lutoslawski]] and [[Henri Dutilleux]].
== Work ==
=== Conducting ===
His extensive concert activity links him with orchestras in Israel and [[Europe]]:<ref>[https://portal.dnb.de/opac.htm?query=shambadal&method=simpleSearch Catalog of the German National Library]</ref> * 1980 principal conductor of the Haifa Symphony Orchestra * 1986–1993 Head of the Kibbutz Chamber Orchestra in Tel Aviv, with which he undertook numerous tours throughout Europe * 1993 until the end of the 2000 chief musical director of the Pfalztheater Kaiserslautern, where he was also engaged in the opening a new theater * Since 1997, principal conductor of the [[Berliner Symphoniker]]<ref>[http://www.berliner-symphoniker.de/dirigenten/ The Berliner Symphoniker] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308111812/http://www.berliner-symphoniker.de/dirigenten/ |date=2016-03-08 }}</ref> * 2000 to 2003 principal conductor of the [[RTV Slovenia Symphony Orchestra]], in [[Ljubljana]] * 2008 to 2010 principal conductor of the [[Bogotá Philharmonic]] Orchestra in [[Colombia]]
Lior Shambadal is known internationally through his CD and television productions, as well as through appearances as a guest conductor with international orchestras.
=== Composer === He is the founder of the composer group ensemble, Acoustic 7/11 and the ensemble for new music – Musica Nova – he has also risen to prominence as a composer in various fields, ranging from [[chamber music]] through song compositions to [[Symphony|symphonic]] works.
=== Teaching === As a teacher he gives masterclasses for conductors including in Canada, Italy and Berlin, in which the participants learn critical aspects of conducting, studying the score, musical analysis, conducting technique and principals of working with singers.<ref>[http://www.international-masterclasses-berlin.de/masterclass-with-lior-shambadal Masterclass-with-lior-shambadal]</ref>
