{{About||the footballer|Nicholas D'Agostino (footballer)|the supermarket founder|Nicholas D'Agostino, Sr.}} {{Infobox person | name = Nicholas D'Agostino | image = Nicholas D'Agostino in 2016.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = Nicholas D'Agostino | birth_name = Nicholas Albert D'Agostino | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|08|15|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Wantage]], [[New Jersey]] | occupation = Motivational Speaker
Author
Coach
Radio Host
Nonprofit Founder
Entrepreneur | years_active = 2005–present }} '''Nicholas Albert "Nick" D'Agostino''' (born August 15, 1989) is an American motivational speaker,http://www.njherald.com/story/25209633/2014/04/10/wantage-speaker-aims-to-spread-motivational-message, author, coach, radio host, nonprofit founder, and entrepreneur from Wantage, New Jersey. Along with his identical twin brother, Anthony, he was diagnosed with [[spinal muscular atrophy]] at 18 months old and started using an electric wheelchair at the age of 6; he received a full posterior stainless steel rod around his spine at the age of 8. He performed orations at hundreds of shows, benefits, and open mics events, e.g. his poem "My Heroine" at the March Against Heroinhttp://www.northjersey.com/news/97132909_Thanks_to_March_Against_Heroin_participants.html to hundreds of people, including addicts and recovering addicts, at [[Mountain Creek]], in Vernon, New Jersey, and at [[MDA Show of Strength]], where he performed his poem "Gravity,"http://classifieds.njherald.com/story/news/07MDATELETHON to raise nearly 1 million dollars for the Muscular Dystrophy Association"{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}. In 2012, D'Agostino, alongside his brother Anthony, launched his own online radio show called ANTagoNICKs,http://ANTagoNICKs.com, which had 71 episodes, and numerous shows with over 1,000 listeners. In the same year he founded The Safe Heaven,http://TheSafeHeaven.org The Safe Heaven, a nonprofit organization which focuses on "helping people realize their potential and self-worth." Through an online forum, their social media sites, and local events, The Safe Heaven has interacted with thousands of individuals. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * http://NicholasDAgostino.com * http://TheSafeHeaven.org * http://ANTagoNICKs.com {{DEFAULTSORT:D'Agostino, Nicholas}} [[Category:1989 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Wantage Township, New Jersey]] [[Category:American motivational speakers]] [[Category:American spoken word artists]] [[Category:Writers from New Jersey]] [[Category:Identical twins]] [[Category:Twin people from the United States]] [[Category:People with spinal muscular atrophy]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=January 2013}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2008}} {{Infobox person |name = Nkosi Johnson |image = |caption = |birth_name = Xolani Nkosi |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1989|2|4}} |birth_place = |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2001|6|1|1989|2|4}} |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = AIDS awareness |occupation = |nationality = {{ZAF}} }} '''Nkosi Johnson''' (born '''Xolani Nkosi'''; {{birth date|df=yes|1989|2|4}} – {{death date|df=yes|2001|6|1}}) was a [[South Africa]]n child with [[HIV]]/[[AIDS]], who made a powerful impact on public perceptions of the [[AIDS pandemic|pandemic]] and its effects before his death at the age of 12. He was ranked fifth amongst [[SABC3's Great South Africans]].{{cite news | title = The 10 Greatest South Africans of all time | publisher = BizCommunity | date = 2004-09-27 | url = http://www.biz-community.com/Article.aspx?ai=4673&c=11 | accessdate = 2008-06-03}} At the time of his death, he was the longest-surviving HIV-positive born child.[http://www.nkosi.iafrica.com/contentPage.asp?pageID=5 About Nkosi] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070824034504/http://www.nkosi.iafrica.com/contentPage.asp?pageID=5 |date=24 August 2007 }} at [http://www.nkosi.iafrica.com/index.html Nkosi's Haven]. Retrieved on 2008-06-03. Nkosi was born to Nonthlanthla Daphne Nkosi in a village near [[Dannhauser]] in 1989.[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4195336 "One Boy's Heroism in the Face of Aids"] ''NPR.org'' [Retrieved 27 March 2013] He never knew his father. Nkosi was HIV-positive from birth, and was legally [[adoption|adopted]] by Gail Johnson, a Johannesburg Public Relations practitioner, when his own mother, debilitated by the disease, was no longer able to care for him.{{cite news | title = Nkosi Johnson dies as he lived, a symbol of the tragedy of Aids |first=Mary|last=Braid | publisher = The Independent| date = 2001-06-02 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/nkosi-johnson-dies-as-he-lived-a-symbol-of-the-tragedy-of-aids-672533.html | accessdate = 2008-06-03}} The young Nkosi Johnson first came to public attention in 1997, when a primary school in the Johannesburg suburb of [[Melville, South Africa|Melville]] refused to accept him as a pupil because of his HIV-positive status. The incident caused a furor at the highest political level—South Africa's [[Constitution of South Africa|Constitution]] forbids [[discrimination]] on the grounds of medical status—and the school later reversed its decision. Nkosi's birth mother died of HIV/AIDS in the same year that he started school. His own condition steadily worsened over the years, although, with the help of medication and treatment, he was able to lead a fairly active life at school and at home. Nkosi was the keynote speaker at the 13th [[International AIDS Conference]], where he encouraged people with HIV/AIDS to be open about the disease and to seek equal treatment. Nkosi finished his speech with the words:[http://www.nkosi.iafrica.com/contentPage.asp?pageID=7 Nkosi's Speech] at [http://www.nkosi.iafrica.com/index.html Nkosi's Haven]. Retrieved on 2008-06-03.
"Care for us and accept us — we are all human beings. We are normal. We have hands. We have feet. We can walk, we can talk, we have needs just like everyone else — don't be afraid of us — we are all the same!"
[[Nelson Mandela]] referred to Nkosi as an "icon of the struggle for life."{{cite news | title = Profile: Mandela's magic touch | publisher = BBC | date = 2001-08-28 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/1513244.stm | accessdate = 2008-06-04}} Together with his foster mother, Nkosi founded a refuge for HIV positive mothers and their children, [[Nkosi's Haven]], in [[Johannesburg]]. In November 2005, Gail represented Nkosi when he posthumously received the [[International Children's Peace Prize]] from the hands of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]].[http://childrenspeaceprize.org/ICPP%202005%20Infosheet.pdf 2005 Infosheet International Children's Peace Prize] [[Nkosi's Haven]] received a prize of US $100,000 from the [[KidsRights Foundation]]. Nkosi is buried at the [[Westpark Cemetery]] in Johannesburg. ==Legacy== * Nkosi's life is the subject of the book ''We Are All the Same'' by [[Jim Wooten]].{{cite book | last = Wooten | first = Jim | title = We Are All the Same: A Story of a Boy's Courage and a Mother's Love | publisher = [[Penguin Books]] | year = 2005 | isbn = 978-0-14-303599-2}} * Poet [[M. K. Asante]] dedicated his 2005 book ''Beautiful. And Ugly Too'' to Nkosi. The book also features a poem entitled "The Spirit of Nkosi Johnson."{{cite book | last = Asante, Jr. | first = M.K. | title = Beautiful. And Ugly Too | publisher = Africa World Press | year = 2005 | isbn = 978-1-59221-422-8}} *A song titled "Do All You Can" subtitled Nkosi's song was recorded by the spiritual musical group Devotion. * Nkosi's words are the inspiration of the song "We Are All the Same" written by NALEDi in June 2001. This song was recorded and released on her 2003 album ''In The Rain''. * The head office of [[CAFCASS]] at the [[Department for Education and Skills (United Kingdom)|Department for Education and Skills]] (Sanctuary Buildings), London has a meeting room named after Johnson. * [[Stellenbosch University]] has a residence named after him at their Medical Campus in [[Tygerberg]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * [http://www.beholders.org/spirit/inspirationalpeople/110-nkosijohson.html Biography and Speech made by Nkosi during AIDS conference] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Johnson, Nkosi}} [[Category:1989 births]] [[Category:2001 deaths]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS activists]] [[Category:South African adoptees]] [[Category:South African child activists]] [[Category:AIDS-related deaths in South Africa]] [[Category:South African children]] [[Category:People from KwaZulu-Natal]]

{{Infobox person | name = Nnamdi Moweta | image = | | birth_date = {{Birth date and age |1958|03|27}} | birth_place = [[Jos Plateau]], Nigeria | | occupation = Radio Host, Music Promoter, Boxing Promoter | website = {{URL|www.Afrodicia.com}} }}
'''Nnamdi Moweta''' (born March 27, 1958), is a radio personality, music producer, music supervisor, music promoter and consultant. He is the host of Radio Afrodicia, a radio show on [[KPFK]], a listener-sponsored radio station based in Los Angeles, California. With an audience of approximately 50,000 listeners weekly,<ref>http://www.channelstv.com/global/news_details.php?cat=Entertainment&nid=24371</ref> Moweta is the only African-born radio host in Los Angeles, California. In 2011, Moweta was featured on [[Reuters]] Africa Journal segment about African DJs in the United States.<ref>http://www.since.szczytno.pl/videos/Africajournal</ref>
Moweta is recognized by UCLA's ethnomusicology program as an expert in the field of African and African-influenced music—he has served as a panelist for UCLA's annual ethnomusicology conferences which attempt to educate the public about global arts and cultures.<ref>http://www.fowler.ucla.edu/events/fowler-outspoken-panel-sonic-nigeria</ref><ref>https://www.scribd.com/doc/20035944/Africa-Meets-North-America</ref>
== Early life == Originally from Jos Plateau State Nigeria, Moweta grew up in Jos, Minna, Kano and Lagos. He speaks [[Igbo language|Igbo]] and Yoruba fluently and is [[Igbo people|Igbo]]. In 1978, Moweta came to the US to study film-making at the San Francisco Art Institute. He moved to Los Angeles in 1982 and established himself as a DJ, music supervisor, consultant, manager, and event promoter. In 1983, Moweta received a grant from the Department of Cultural Affairs in Los Angeles to host an eight-week segment about the origins of rap music. The program aired on KPFK that year and afterwards, Moweta was asked by KPFK to host a weekly show and subsequently, Radio Afrodicia began broadcasting on June 21, 1995.
== Career == === Radio host === Moweta currently hosts Radio Afrodicia, which features both internationally-known and new musicians.<ref>http://www.kpfk.org/programs/41-afrodicia.html</ref><ref>https://www.vpop.net/~kpfk/programs/program_AD.shtml</ref> Moweta has interviewed well-known artists such as [[Fela Kuti]], Seun Kuti, Femi Kuti, [[Baaba Maal]], [[Papa Wemba]], [[Youssou N'Dour]], Asa and Fally Ipupa. For over twenty years, Moweta has increased the US exposure of African artists such as Fela Kuti, [[King Sunny Adé]], Chief Stephen Osita Osadebe, [[Koffi Olomide]], and [[Nneka (singer)|Nneka]].<ref>http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jun/05/news/wk-out5</ref><ref>http://www.inthesetimes.com/issue/26/19/culture2.shtml</ref>
Moweta said, "I've been doing this show for almost 15 years. The concept is bringing music from Africa into the Western world into the African world because music from Africa is pretty large and big. We live in a diverse city, Los Angeles; we have Cubans, you have Brazilians, you have Jamaicans you know." <ref>http://www.channelstv.com/global/news_details.php?cat=Entertainment&nid=24371</ref> Radio Afrodicia plays a blend of a wide range of African-influenced sounds including: [[Afro-beat]], Afro-Pop, Bachata, Soukous, Hi-Life, Rumba (Congolese and Cuban), Salsa (African and Latin American), Samba, and Soca. The show not only highlights musicians performing in all regions of Africa, but also features African musicians performing in other areas of the world and non-African musicians who draw upon African traditions for their musical inspiration.
=== Music promoter === For several years, Moweta has promoted and supported local events in Los Angeles that educate the public about African culture and music. One of his largest and longest-running events was the African Village Festival held at the John Anson Ford Amphitheatre in Hollywood. From 1997-2003, Moweta produced the annual African Village Festival, which showcased music from all over Africa, Brazil, and Cuba.<ref>https://www.vpop.net/~kpfk/programs/program_AD.shtml</ref><ref>http://articles.latimes.com/1999/mar/24/entertainment/ca-20370</ref><ref>https://www.vpop.net/~kpfk/news_20020730.html</ref> <ref>http://www.lacountyarts.org/temp/ford_sumseason_world.html</ref> The Festival had a significant impact on the popularity of African music in Los Angeles, in that performers such as Papa Wemba steadily gained a U.S. following.<ref>http://soukous.com/Papa_Wemba/</ref> International artists such as [[M'bilia Bel]], [[Kanda Bongo Man]], Papa Wemba, [[Diblo Dibala]], and Madilu System all were featured performers for the festival.<ref>https://www.vpop.net/~kpfk/programs/program_AD.shtml</ref><ref>http://articles.latimes.com/1999/mar/24/entertainment/ca-20370 </ref><ref>https://www.vpop.net/~kpfk/news_20020730.html</ref> <ref>http://www.lacountyarts.org/temp/ford_sumseason_world.html</ref>
=== Music producer and manager === In 1995, Moweta managed [[Chief Stephen Osita Osadebe]], the Nigerian performer who rose to international fame as the leading contributor of African popular music, known as highlife.<ref>http://www.inthesetimes.com/issue/26/19/culture2.shtml</ref><ref>http://www.boston.com/news/globe/obituaries/articles/2007/05/20/chief_stephen_osita_osadebe_71_titan_of_highlife_music/</ref><ref>Eds. Broughton, S., Ellingham, M. & Lusk, J. The Rough Guide to World Music Africa and Middle East, 2006</ref> Moweta oversaw Osadebe's four-month concert tour of North America and co-produced four of Osadebe's CDs with Andy Frankel, two of which, Kedu America and Club América, were released in 1996.<ref>http://www.inthesetimes.com/issue/26/19/culture2.shtml</ref>
=== Music supervisor === In 2008, Moweta was the music supervisor for the winner of eight international film festival awards, ''Kassim the Dream''.<ref>http://www.kassimthedream.com</ref> The documentary is about [[Kassim Ouma]], Ugandan child soldier became IBF Light Middleweight Champion in 2004. Later, in 2009, Moweta again lent his talents to film, and was the music supervisor for ''40'', a Turkish film that casts both Turkish and African actors.<ref>https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3751458/</ref>
=== Boxing promoter === For several years, beginning in 1984, Moweta managed a stable of fighters called the "Warrior Family from Africa." The stable included [[Prince Mama Mohammed]] <ref>http://articles.latimes.com/1986-04-14/sports/sp-3804_1_prince-mohammed</ref> from Ghana who fought for the WBC Light Heavyweight World Title Championship in December 1985. Mohammed ended his career with 30 wins, 3 losses, and 2 draws. Moweta's stable also included Nigerian welterweight, [[Young Dick Tiger]], the nephew of former world middleweight champion [[Dick Tiger]].<ref>http://articles.latimes.com/1986-11-14/sports/sp-29418_1_state-title</ref>
In 2011, Moweta interviewed Nigerian boxer, [[Samuel Peter]], before Peter's world heavyweight title challenge against [[Wladimir Klitschko]] for the Africa Channel's sports documentary, ''Boxing Before the Bell''.<ref>http://www.theafricachannel.com/featuredvideos.php</ref> Moweta also interviewed world-renowned boxing trainer, [[Freddie Roach (boxing)|Freddie Roach]], and [[Lateef Kayode]], another Nigerian boxer for ''Boxing Before the Bell''.
=== Interviewer === Moweta is an interviewer/commentator for several international news programs, including BBC Africa's sports show, ''Fast Track'', The Voice of America's African sports show,<ref>http://blogs.voanews.com/sonny/2011/08/15/king-kong-was-robbed/ http://www.voafanti.com/gate/big5/blogs.voanews.com/sonny/2011/06/09/ </ref> and ''Network Africa'', a BBC morning show that discusses current trends in African music.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14651145</ref> Additionally, Moweta covers Hollywood news for the BBC evening program ''Africa World''.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/africa/2011/09/110922_african_performance_2011_second_prize_silhouettes.shtml</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox writer | name = Oliver Gogarty | image = Orpen_OSJGogarty.jpg | caption = Oliver Gogarty as painted in 1911 by [[William Orpen]] | birth_name = Oliver Joseph St. John Gogarty | birth_date = {{Birth date|1878|8|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Parnell Square|Rutland Square]], Dublin, Ireland | death_date = {{death date and age|1957|9|22|1878|8|17|df=y}} | death_place = New York City, United States | spouse = Martha Duane Gogarty | occupation = Author, poet, memoirist, surgeon, politician, athlete | movement = Irish Literary Renaissance | notableworks = ''[[As I Was Going Down Sackville Street]]'' (1937)}}
{{MedalTop}} {{MedalSport | [[Art competitions at the Summer Olympics|Art competitions]]}} {{MedalBronze | [[1924 Summer Olympics|1924 Paris]] | [[Art competitions at the 1924 Summer Olympics|Literature]]}} {{MedalBottom}}
'''Oliver Joseph St John Gogarty''' (17 August 1878 – 22 September 1957) was an Irish poet, author, [[otolaryngologist]], athlete, politician, and well-known conversationalist. He served as the inspiration for [[Buck Mulligan]] in [[James Joyce]]'s novel ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]''.
==Life==
===Early life=== Gogarty was born 17 August 1878 in [[Parnell Square|Rutland Square]], Dublin, the eldest child of Henry Gogarty, a well-to-do Dublin physician, and Margaret Gogarty (née Oliver), the daughter of a [[Galway]] mill owner.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://civilrecords.irishgenealogy.ie/churchrecords/details-civil/7adc675723754|title=General Registrar's Office|last=|first=|date=|website=IrishGenealogy.ie|publisher=|access-date=17 August 2017}}</ref> Three siblings (Henry, Mary, and Richard) were born later. Gogarty's father, himself the son of a medical doctor, had been educated at [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]] and owned two fashionable homes in Dublin, which set the Gogartys apart from other [[Irish Catholic]] families at that time and allowed them access to the same social circles as the [[Protestant Ascendancy]].<ref>O'Connor, pp.12-13</ref>
In 1887 Gogarty's father died of a [[Appendicitis|burst appendix]], and Gogarty was sent to [[Mungret College]], a boarding school near [[Limerick]]. He was unhappy in his new school, and the following year he transferred to [[Stonyhurst College]] in Lancashire, England, which he liked little better, later referring to it as "a religious jail".<ref>{{cite book |title= It Isn't This Time of Year at All! |last= Gogarty |first= Oliver |year= 1954 |publisher= Doubleday & Company, Inc. |location= New York |page= 41}}</ref>
Gogarty returned to Ireland in 1896 and boarded at [[Clongowes Wood College]] while studying for examinations with the [[Royal University of Ireland]]. He was a talented athlete; in England he had briefly played for the [[Preston North End FC]] Reserve, and while at [[Clongowes Wood College|Clongowes]] he played for the [[Bohemian FC]]. He also played on Clongowes's soccer and [[cricket]] elevens. His extracurricular interests, which also included cycling and drinking, prevented him from being an attentive student, and in 1898 he switched to the medical school at [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]], having failed eight of his ten [[examinations]] at the [[Royal University of Ireland|Royal]].<ref>O'Connor, pp. 14–16</ref>
===University days=== As one of [[Dublin]]'s "[[medical student|medicos]]", Gogarty was known to be fond of public [[pranks]]<ref>O'Connor, pp. 22–23</ref> and midnight carousing in "the Kips", Dublin's red-light district.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 54–55</ref> He had a talent for [[light poetry|humorous]] and [[ribaldry|bawdy verse]], which quickly made the rounds through the city, and sometimes composed [[mnemonic]] lyrics to aid his [[medical school|medical studies]]. He also enjoyed a highly successful cycling career before being banned from the tracks in 1901 for bad language, and between 1898 and 1901 he rescued at least four people from drowning.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 24–25, 39</ref> He became interested in [[Irish nationalism]] after meeting [[Arthur Griffith]] in 1899, and contributed propaganda pieces to ''[[United Irishman|The United Irishman]]'' over subsequent years.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 92–93</ref>
[[File:OSJGogarty1897.jpg|thumb|left|Gogarty in 1897]]
A serious interest in poetry and literature also began to manifest itself during his years at Trinity. His witty conversation made him a favourite with the [[university don|dons]], particularly [[John Pentland Mahaffy]] (formerly the tutor of [[Oscar Wilde]]) and [[Robert Yelverton Tyrrell]], and between 1901 and 1903 he won three successive Vice-Chancellor's prizes for verse. In 1900 he made the acquaintance of [[W. B. Yeats]] (of whom his mother highly approved) and of [[George Moore (novelist)|George Moore]] (of whom she did not) and began to frequent [[Celtic revival|Dublin literary circles]].<ref>O'Connor, pp. 29–30</ref> He also formed close friendships with other up-and-coming young poets, such as [[Seamus O'Sullivan]] and [[James Joyce]]. In 1904 he spent two [[academic term|terms]] at [[Oxford]] to compete for the [[Newdigate Prize]], but lost to [[George Bell (bishop)|G.K.A. Bell]], the future [[Bishop of Chichester]], who became a friend and frequent correspondent over the next few years.<ref>O'Connor, pp71-75</ref>
[[File:James Joyce Martello Tower.jpg|thumb|right|The Tower in Sandycove]]
Upon returning to Dublin in the summer of 1904, Gogarty made arrangements to rent the famous [[James Joyce Tower|Martello Tower in Sandycove]]. The primary goal of this scheme, as described by Gogarty in a letter to G.K.A. Bell, was to "house the Bard" (i.e. James Joyce), who was without money and required "a year in which to finish his novel."<ref>{{cite book |title= Many Lines to Thee |last= Carens |first= James |year= 1972 |publisher= Dolmen Press |location= Dublin |page= 16}}</ref> The two friends quarrelled in August, however, and Joyce either failed to move in or left shortly after doing so. Joyce briefly took up residence in the [[James Joyce Tower|Tower]] the following month, together with Gogarty and his Oxford friend Samuel Chenevix Trench (a setup which later provided inspiration for the opening chapter of ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]])'' but left again suddenly after only six days.<ref>Ellman, p.175</ref> Forty years later in America, Gogarty would attribute Joyce's abrupt departure to his and S.C. Trench's midnight antics with a loaded [[revolver]].<ref>{{cite book |title= Mourning Became Mrs. Spendlove |last= Gogarty |first= Oliver |year= 1948 |publisher= Creative Age Press |location= New York |pages= 56–57}}</ref> Joyce and Gogarty corresponded intermittently during the early years of Joyce's continental exile and occasionally planned meetings, but contemporaneous letters from Joyce to his brother reveal deep distrust of Gogarty's motives,<ref>Ellmann, p. 842</ref> and their friendship was never fully renewed. Gogarty made use of the Martello Tower during the following year as a writing retreat and party venue, and officially held the lease until 1925.
In 1904 and 1905 Gogarty published several short poems in the London publication ''The Venture'' and in [[William Kirkpatrick Magee|John Eglinton]]'s journal ''Dana''.<ref>Carens (1979) p. 22</ref> His name also appeared in print as the renegade priest Fr. Oliver Gogarty in George Moore's 1905 novel ''The Lake'', an occurrence which upset Gogarty's devout mother.<ref>O'Connor, 107–108</ref> In 1905 Gogarty became one of the founding members of [[Arthur Griffith]]'s [[Sinn Féin]], a [[nonviolent revolution|non-violent political movement]] with a plan for Irish autonomy modelled after the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian dual monarchy]].<ref>O'Connor, p. 89</ref>
===Medical career and family=== [[File:Nollgogarty.jpg|thumb|right|Noll Gogarty, painted by [[William Orpen]]]] In August 1906, Gogarty married Martha Duane, a girl from a landowning [[Connemara]] family. Eager to establish himself with a profession, he passed his final medical examinations in June 1907, several months after the death of his mother. In July 1907 his first son, Oliver Duane Odysseus Gogarty (known as "Noll") was born, and in autumn of that year Gogarty left for [[Vienna]] to finish the practical phase of his medical training. Owing in part to the influence of his mentor, [[Robert Henry Woods|Sir Robert Woods]], Gogarty had decided to specialise in [[otolaryngology]], and in [[Vienna]] he studied under [[Ottokar Chiari]], Markus Hajek, and [[Robert Bárány]].
Returning to Dublin in 1908, Gogarty secured a post at Richmond Hospital, and shortly afterwards purchased a house in Ely Place opposite George Moore. Three years later, he joined the staff of the [[Meath Hospital]] and remained there for the remainder of his medical career. He became known for flamboyant theatrics in the [[operating room]], including off-the-cuff witticisms and the flinging of recently removed [[larynx]]es at the viewing gallery. He also maintained [[otolaryngology|ENT]] consulting rooms in [[Ely Place]], attracting a number of wealthy clients and attending to less well-off patients for free.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 113–127</ref>
Gogarty and his wife went on to have two more children, [[Dermot St. John Gogarty|Dermot]] (born 1908) and Brenda (born 1911), and in 1917 Gogarty purchased Renyvle House, a large [[country house]] in [[Renvyle]], [[Connemara]]. He became a keen [[motorist]] during this time, purchasing a succession of [[cars]] that culminated with a buttercup-coloured [[Rolls-Royce Limited|Rolls Royce]].<ref>O'Connor, p. 121</ref> During the following decade he was also interested in aviation, earning a [[pilot's licence]] and helping to found the Irish Aero Club.<ref>O'Connor, p. 232</ref>
===Free State Senator=== As a [[Sinn Féin]]er during the [[Irish War of Independence]], Gogarty participated in a variety of anti-[[Black and Tans|Black and Tan]] schemes, allowing his home to be used as a [[safe house]] and transporting disguised [[Irish Republican Army|IRA]] volunteers in his car.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 173–174</ref> Following the [[ratification]] of the [[Anglo-Irish Treaty]], Gogarty sided with the [[Irish Free State|pro-Treaty government]] (headed by his close friend [[Arthur Griffith]]) and was made a [[Seanad Éireann|Free State Senator]].<ref name=oireachtas_db>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtas.ie/members-hist/default.asp?housetype=1&HouseNum=1922&MemberID=1338&ConstID=214|title=Dr. Oliver St. John Gogarty|work=Oireachtas Members Database|accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> When Griffith fell ill during the summer of 1922, Gogarty frequently attended his bedside. His death on 12 August 1922 had a profound effect on Gogarty; W.T. Cosgrave later observed that "he was almost mortally wounded when Griffith died, he was so very, very much attached to him."<ref>{{cite book |title= Irish Literary Portraits |last= Rodgers |first= William |year= 1973 |publisher= Taplinger Publishers |location= New York |page= 153}}</ref> Gogarty carried out Griffith's official [[autopsy]] and [[embalmment]], and went on to perform the same offices for [[Michael Collins (Irish leader)|Michael Collins]], another close friend whom Gogarty had often sheltered in his Ely Place home prior to his assassination. It was rumoured that Griffith had been planning to make Gogarty the new [[Governor-General of the Irish Free State]], but in his absence the post went to [[Timothy Michael Healy|Tim Healy]].<ref>O'Connor, p. 97</ref>
[[File:Gogarty1922.jpg|thumb|left|Gogarty in 1922]]
In November 1922, anti-Treaty [[Irish Republican Army|IRA]] commander [[Liam Lynch (Irish republican)|Liam Lynch]] issued a general order to his forces to shoot [[Seanad Éireann|Free State Senators]]. Two months later, Gogarty was [[Kidnapping|kidnapped]] by a group of anti-Treaty militants, who lured him out of his house and into a waiting car under the pretext of bringing him to visit a sick patient. Gogarty was subsequently driven to an empty house near [[Chapelizod]] and held under armed guard. Aware that he might be in imminent danger of execution, Gogarty contrived to have himself led out into the garden (purportedly by claiming to be suffering from [[diarrhoea]]), where he broke free from his captors and flung himself into the [[River Liffey|Liffey]]; he then swam to shore and delivered himself to the protection of the police barracks in [[Phoenix Park]]. In February of that same year, [[Destruction of Irish country houses (1919-1923)|Renvyle was burnt to the ground]] by anti-Treaty forces. Following these incidents, Gogarty relocated his family and practice to London, where he resided until February 1924. Upon returning to Ireland, he famously released two swans into the [[River Liffey]] in gratitude for his life.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 194–199</ref>
Gogarty remained a senator until the abolition of the [[Seanad Éireann|Seanad]] in 1936, during which time he identified with none of the existing political parties and voted according to his own whims. He believed that Ireland should retain its dominion status in the [[British Commonwealth]] so as to "keep with nations who understand that the first principle of freedom is a freedom that does not permit interference with the personal liberties of the citizen." He supported rural electrification schemes, road improvement, [[reforestation]] and [[Conservation movement|conservation]], prevention of livestock cruelty, and [[educational reform]]. His views on controversial issues such as censorship and [[birth control]] were ambiguous; after expressing initial support for the Censorship Bill, he eventually went on to denounce it in scathing terms ("I think it is high time the men of this country found some other way of loving God than by hating women"), and while generally professing to oppose the sale of prophylactics, he voiced support for their usage in certain cases. He was most passionate on the subject of sanitation in schools and in urban and rural housing, about which he spoke frequently.<ref>Carens (1979) pp.112–113</ref> His speeches frequently contained [[pun]]s, wordplays, and extended poetic quotations, and were sometimes given in favour of facetious schemes, such as his attempt to have the [[Phoenix (mythology)|phoenix]] statue in [[Phoenix Park]] included in the 1929 Wild Birds Protection Bill.<ref>Historical Debates Website. Seanad Éireann Wild Birds Protection Bill, 1929—Report. Tithe an Oireachteas. 19 August 2009. {{cite web |url=http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0013/S.0013.192912120007 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607135429/http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0013/S.0013.192912120007 |archivedate=7 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He was notoriously scornful of the government's attempts to reinstate the [[Irish language]] (which he referred to as "Woolworth's Irish"), proposing that funding be used instead for housing and school health services,<ref>Historical Debates Website. Seanad Éireann Central Fund Bill, 1936—Report and Final Stages. Tithe an Oireachteas. 19 August 2009. {{cite web |url=http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0020/S.0020.193603250004.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607135500/http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0020/S.0020.193603250004.html |archivedate=7 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and remained perpetually suspicious of [[Éamon de Valera]], against whose economic policies, character, and personal appearance he often hurled invectives during Seanad proceedings. [[Éamon de Valera|De Valera]] eventually dissolved the Seanad when it persisted in obstructing Government proposals, effectively ending Gogarty's political career.<ref>O'Connor, pp.246–254</ref>
===Literary endeavours=== Gogarty maintained close friendships with [[W. B. Yeats]], [[George William Russell|AE]], George Moore, [[Lord Dunsany]], [[James Stephens (author)|James Stephens]], [[Seamus O'Sullivan]], and other Dublin literati, and continued to write poetry in the midst of his political and professional duties. Three small books of poetry (''Hyperthuleana'', ''Secret Springs of Dublin Song'', and ''The Ship and Other Poems'') were published between 1916 and 1918.<ref>Carens, pp. 31–37</ref> Gogarty also tried his hand at [[playwriting]], producing a slum drama (''[[Blight (play)|Blight]]'') in 1917 under the pseudonym "Alpha and Omega", and two comedies (''A Serious Thing'' and ''The Enchanted Trousers'') in 1919 under the pseudonym "[[Gideon Ouseley]]", all three of which were performed at the [[Abbey Theatre]].<ref>Carens, pp. 42–46</ref>
Gogarty devoted less energy to his medical practice and more to his writing during the twenties and thirties. His 1924 book of poetry ''An Offering of Swans'' won the Gold Medal for poetry at the revived [[Tailteann Games (Irish Free State)|Tailteann Games]], for which he also wrote the 1924 Olympic bronze medal-winning ''Tailteann Ode'' (which he was later to describe as "rather tripe").<ref>Carens, p. 23</ref> In 1929 another book of verse, ''Wild Apples'', was published, and was followed in 1933 by ''Selected Poems''. Gogarty was also a member of [[W. B. Yeats|Yeats]]'s Irish Academy of Letters and frequently assisted in arranging its social functions. 1936 saw the publication of [[W. B. Yeats|Yeats]]'s ''[[Oxford Book of Modern Verse]]'', which contained seventeen of Gogarty's poems and an introduction proclaiming him "one of the great lyric poets of our age."<ref>O'Connor, p. 255</ref> The over-representation given to Gogarty outraged many poets and perplexed Gogarty himself, who remarked, "What right have I to figure so bulkily? None from a poetical point of view... [[Sappho]] herself could not have made a more subjective anthology."<ref>Carens, p. 266</ref>
In 1935 Gogarty published his first prose work, ''[[As I Was Going Down Sackville Street]]'' (subtitled "A Phantasy in Fact"), a semi-fictional novel-memoir that tells, in reverse chronological order, the story of Gogarty's Dublin through a series of interconnected anecdotes and lively characters sketches. Shortly after its publication, it became the subject of a lawsuit by a Jewish [[art dealer]], Harry Sinclair, who claimed that he and his recently deceased twin brother, William Sinclair, had been [[libel]]ed by the publication. The two men did not appear as named characters in the book, but some derogatory lines of verse beginning ''"Two Jews grew in Sackville Street"'', written by Gogarty's friend George Redding and included in a scene in the novel, were widely known to refer to the Sinclair siblings. Harry Sinclair further recognised a reference to his grandfather, described in the text as one who "enticed little girls into his office", an offence of which his grandfather had in fact been convicted. Gogarty responded to the charges by claiming that the unnamed Jews were parodies or composite characters rather than deliberate evocations of living persons.<ref>O'Connor, pp.280–283</ref> The case attracted a great deal of public attention, with one commentator observing that "only ''[[The Pickwick Papers]]'', rewritten by James Joyce, could really capture the mood of this trial."<ref>O'Connor, p. 279</ref> Among the witnesses for the prosecution was William Sinclair's nephew-by-marriage, [[Samuel Beckett]], then a little-known writer, who was humiliatingly denounced as a "bawd and blasphemer" by Gogarty's counsel.<ref>{{cite book |title= Damned to Fame: The Life of Samuel Beckett |last= Knowlson |first= James |year= 1996 |publisher= Bloomsbury |location= London}}</ref> Gogarty ultimately lost the lawsuit and was ordered to pay £900 in damages, plus court costs. This outcome deeply embittered Gogarty, who had already suffered financial setbacks after the [[stock market crash of 1929]]<ref>{{cite book |title= W. B. Yeats: A Life, Vol. II: The Arch-Poet 1915–1939 |last= Foster |first= Robert |year= 2003 |publisher= Oxford University Press |location= Oxford |page= 405}}</ref> and felt that the verdict had been politically motivated.<ref>O'Connor, p. 284</ref>
In spite of the ''Sackville Street'' imbroglio, Gogarty's output over the next two years was prolific. In 1938 he published ''I Follow St. Patrick'', a historical and geographic portrait of Ireland as told through Gogarty's rambling visits to various sites traditionally associated with [[St. Patrick]]; in 1939 he published ''Tumbling in the Hay'', a semi-autobiographical comic novel about medical students in turn-of-the-century Dublin, and ''Elbow Room'', another collection of poetry. In 1938 he relocated to London for a second time and brought forth his own libel suit against the young poet [[Patrick Kavanagh]], whose autobiography ''The Green Fool'' said of [[Patrick Kavanagh|Kavanagh]]'s first visit to Gogarty's home: "I mistook Gogarty's white-robed maid for his wife or his mistress; I expected every poet to have a spare wife." Gogarty, who had taken offence at the close coupling of the words "wife" and "mistress", was awarded £100 in damages.<ref>{{cite book |title= Patrick Kavanagh |last= O'Brien |first= Darcy |year= 1975 |publisher= Bucknell University Press |location= Lewisburg |page= 29}}</ref>
===American years=== With the onset of [[World War II]], Gogarty, who was an enthusiastic and talented amateur [[aviator]], attempted to enlist in the [[RAF]] and the [[RAMC]] as a doctor. He was denied on grounds of age. He then departed in September 1939 for an extended lecture tour in the United States, leaving his wife to manage Renvyle House, which had since been rebuilt as a hotel. When his return to Ireland was delayed by the war, Gogarty applied for [[American citizenship]], and eventually decided to reside permanently in the United States. Though he regularly sent letters, funds, and care-packages to his family and returned home for occasional holiday visits, he never again lived in Ireland for any extended length of time. His primary American residence was in New York, where he was known to frequent bars on [[Third Avenue]]. He also spent time in [[Vermont]] and in Wyckoff, [[New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite book |title= The Renvyle Letters |last= Williams |first= Guy |year= 2000 |publisher= Daletta Press |location= Monasterevan |pages= 1–2}}</ref>
Feeling that he was too old to sit for the medical examinations that would have qualified him as a practitioner in the United States, Gogarty instead chose to support himself entirely by his writing. In addition to various essays and short stories, his prose output included ''Going Native'', a satire on English social mores, ''Mad Grandeur'' and ''Mr. Petunia'', two period narratives composed with an eye to having them optioned as Hollywood films, and ''Rolling Down the Lea'' and ''It Isn't This Time of Year at All!'', two loosely constructed memoirs. He also published two books of poems, ''Perennial'' and ''Unselected Poems''; a collection of bawdy verse, ''The Merry Muses of Hibernia'', was planned but never completed. Gogarty's literary output during the forties and fifties is generally considered to be inferior to his earlier writings.<ref>Williams, p. 2</ref>
Gogarty suffered from heart complaints during the last few years of his life, and in September 1957 he collapsed in the street on his way to dinner. He died on 22 September 1957; his body was flown home to Ireland and buried in Cartron Church, Moyard, near Renvyle.
==Literary portrayal== [[File:Revolutionary Joyce Better Contrast.jpg|thumb|right|James Joyce]] A highly visible and distinctive [[Dublin]] character during his lifetime, Gogarty appears in a number of memoirs penned by his contemporaries, notably George Moore's ''Hail and Farewell'', where he goes both by his own name and by the pseudonym "Conan."<ref>O'Connor, pp. 51–52</ref> His most famous literary incarnation, however, is as [[Buck Mulligan]], the irrepressible roommate of [[Stephen Dedalus]] in James Joyce's ''Ulysses''. Mulligan quotes a number of songs and poems known to have been written by Gogarty,<ref>Carens, pp. 25–26</ref> the most famous of which, [[The Ballad of Japing Jesus|"The Song of the Cheerful (But Slightly Sarcastic) Jesus"]], was originally sent to Joyce as a belated Christmas peace offering after their quarrels of 1904.<ref>Ellmann, p. 214</ref> Other details, such as Mulligan's [[Hellenism (neoclassicism)|Hellenism]], his status as a medical student, his history of saving men from drowning, his friendship with George Moore, and the metrical arrangement of his full name (Malachi Roland St. John Mulligan) parallel Gogarty's biography. Due to his influence on Joyce (he is also sometimes cited as an inspiration for ''[[Dubliners]]'' character Ignatius Gallaher and ''[[Exiles (play)|Exiles]]'' antagonist Robert Hand), Gogarty's name often comes up in Joyce scholarship, though Gogarty's own editors and biographers have complained that these references are frequently inaccurate, owing to Gogarty-related errata in [[James Joyce (biography)|Richard Ellmann's ''James Joyce'']] and a tendency to conflate the real-life Gogarty with the fictional character of Buck Mulligan.<ref>Carens, pp. 10–21</ref>
It has also been suggested{{who|date=November 2012}} that the speaker of W. B. Yeats's poem ''High Talk'', "Malachi Stilt-Jack", is intended to be a representation of Gogarty.<ref>Carens, pp. 7–8</ref>
==Legacy== A pub in the [[Temple Bar, Dublin|Temple Bar]] district of Dublin is named after him, and an annual Oliver St. John Gogarty Literary Festival is held in the author's family home, now the Renvyle House Hotel in [[Connemara]]. A surgical ward in the descendant hospital of his workplace, the [[Tallaght Hospital|AMNCH]], now also bears his name.

'''Patrick Eddington''' is an American author, policy analyst in national security and civil liberties at the [[Cato Institute]], served as a [[CIA]] military [[Imagery analysis|imagery analyst]] ([[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency#National Photographic Interpretation Center .28NPIC.29|National Photographic Interpretation Center]]) from 1988-1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/staff/patrick-g-eddington/|title=Patrick G. Eddington – The Intercept|work=theintercept.com|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
During his tenure at the CIA, his analytical assignments included monitoring the breakup of the former [[Soviet Union]]; providing military assessments to policy makers on [[Iraq]]i and [[Iran]]ian conventional forces and coordinating the CIA's military targeting support to [[NATO]] during [[Operation Deliberate Force]] in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]] in 1995.
Eddington resigned in 1996 after working on a book (''[http://www.patrickeddington.com/gassedinthegulf.html Gassed in the Gulf: The Inside Story of the Pentagon-CIA Cover-up of Gulf War Syndrome]'') where he presented the claim that there is substantial evidence that American soldiers were exposed to chemical agents during the Persian Gulf War in 1991 [[gulf war syndrome]].
His CIA memoir, ''[http://www.patrickeddington.com/longstrangejourn.html Long Strange Journey]'', was published in 2011. In a 2011 interview with the Washington Post, Eddington accused the CIA of still withholding 1.5 million documents relevant to the Desert Storm malady known as gulf war syndrome.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/spy-talk/2011/02/ex-cia_analyst_patrcik_eddingt.html|title=SpyTalk - Ex-CIA analyst Patrick Eddington accuses agency of ‘sitting on’ Gulf War illness documents|work=washingtonpost.com|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
Eddington's opinion pieces have appeared in a number of publications, including the ''[[Washington Post]]'', ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', ''[[Washington Times]]'', ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]'', and the ''[[Army Times]]'', among others. Eddington is a frequent commentator on national security issues for the [[Fox News Channel]], [[MSNBC]], [[SKY News]], [[CNN]], and other domestic and international television networks
== Books == * ''Gassed in the Gulf: The Inside Story of the Pentagon-CIA Cover-up of Gulf War Syndrome'', August 1997, Insignia Publishing Company * ''Long Strange Journey: An Intelligence Memoir'', 2011

{{Chinese|title=P. K. Ojong|collapse=yes|s=欧阳炳昆|t=歐陽炳昆|p=Ōuyáng Bǐngkūn|w=Ouyang Ping-k'un|poj=|ind=Auwjong Peng-koen}}
'''Petrus Kanisius Ojong''' (25 July 1920 – 31 May 1980)<ref name="prominent">{{cite book |title=Prominent Indonesian Chinese: Biographical Sketches (4th edition) |year=2015 |author= Leo Suryadinata |isbn=9814620505 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZO6gCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA209 |pages=209-210}}</ref> was one of the founders of ''[[Kompas]]'', one of [[Indonesia]]'s daily newspapers, together with [[Jakob Oetama]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kompasgramedia.com/about-kg/our-management?term=ourmanagement |accessdate=2017-12-23 |title=Kompas Gramedia Management Team |author=Kompas Gramedia |date=}}</ref>
== Early life == '''Auwjong Peng Koen''' was born in [[Bukittinggi]]<ref name="bio"/> on July 25, 1920. Since childhood, his father, Auwjong Pauw, always taught him to be disciplined, economical, and hard working. His father was a farmer in [[Quemoy]] Island (part of [[Fujian Province, Republic of China|Fujian Province]],now under control of Taiwan). He moved to [[Sumatra]] to get a better job.
Even though eventually Auwjong Pauw became a successful tobacco lord, he never pampered his children. His teachings had really shaped Peng Koen's character. He became a serious and very straightforward person.
Peng Koen attended the [[Hollandsche Chineesche School]] (primary school for the [[Chinese language|Chinese]]).<ref name="prominent"/> During this time he was introduced to [[Catholic]] teachings, and finally converted to Catholicism and received the baptismal name of Andreas.
== Higher education == Peng Koen went to Hollandsche Chineesche Kweekschool to pursue his study. During this time, he was appointed as a leader of students organization. His task was to prepare reading material for the members. Other than that, he also planned the Chinese New Year celebration and year-end picnic.
He loved to read newspapers and magazines. Whereas other students just read the articles, Peng Koen tried to digest the writing styles and the ideas of every articles. It is said that Peng Koen was a bit 'stiff' when he faced the opposite sex. One of his ex-classmates, Oei Yin Hwa, who owned a sweets shop in [[Cianjur]], still remembers that Peng Koen was known as ''verstrooide professor'' or "forgetful professor".<ref>{{cite book |title=P.K. Ojong: hidup sederhana, berpikir mulia |year=2001 |author= Helen Ishwara |isbn=9797090000 |language=id |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hxplAAAAMAAJ&q=%22verstrooide+professor%22+ojong |page=30}}</ref> He was also known for having a serious demeanor.<ref name="bio"/>
== Career Life == Peng Koen was a teacher before he became a journalist.<ref name="bio">{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2001/10/14/pk-ojong-a-simple-life-full-achievement.html |archivedate=2014-01-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104042554/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2001/10/14/pk-ojong-a-simple-life-full-achievement.html |accessdate=2017-12-23 |title=P.K. Ojong -- A simple life full of achievement | newspaper= The Jakarta Post |author=Lie Hua |date=2001-10-14}}</ref> He studied at a teacher's college in Jakarta and worked as a teacher from 1940 to 1942.<ref name="catholic">{{cite book |title=Catholics in Independent Indonesia: 1945-2010 |year=2015 |author= Karel Steenbrink |isbn=9004285423 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=1N8zDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA210 |page=210}}</ref> His career as teacher was ended when Japan attacked Indonesia and closed all the existing school at that time.
He also worked for ''[[Star Weekly (Indonesia)|Star Weekly]]'', a [[Malay language]] weekly which targeted non-Chinese-speaking [[Indonesian Chinese]], starting in 1946.<ref name="bio"/> He continued working there (while sometimes working for other magazines as well) until it was banned in 1960.<ref name="prominent"/> During that time he also had an opportunity to work with [[Felix Tan]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indonesiamedia.com/rubrik/tokoh/tokoh00july.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010222122149/http://www.indonesiamedia.com/rubrik/tokoh/tokoh00july.htm |archivedate=2001-02-22 |accessdate=2017-12-23 |title=Felix Tan (Tan Fay Tjhion) |language=id |date=}}</ref>
== Social Work == PK Ojong actively took part in a social organization called [[Sin Ming Hui]],<ref name="prominent"/> which was established by [[Khoe Woen Sioe]] and [[Injo Beng Goat]]. The organisation was housed in one of Jakarta's best-known historic landmarks, [[Candra Naya]].
== Post Life == PK Ojong died in Jakarta in 1980. His biography, ''PK Ojong: Hidup Sederhana, Berpikir Mulia'' was published in 2001.<ref name="bio"/> The author of the book is Helen Ishwara.<ref name="bio"/> The book contains PK Ojong's experiences with the background of [[Old Order (Indonesia)|Old Order]] and [[New Order (Indonesia)|New Order]]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Quico Canseco |image = Quico Canseco, official portrait, 112th Congress.jpg |state = [[Texas]] |district = {{ushr|TX|23|23rd}} |term_start = January 3, 2011 |term_end = January 3, 2013 |predecessor = [[Ciro Rodriguez]] |successor = [[Pete Gallego]] |birth_name = Francisco Raul Canseco |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|7|30}} |birth_place = [[Laredo, Texas|Laredo]], [[Texas]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Gloria Canseco |children = 3 |education = [[Saint Louis University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |website = {{url|web.archive.org/web/20110108180925/http://canseco.house.gov|Official website}} }} '''Francisco Raul''' "'''Quico'''" '''Canseco'''<ref>[http://www.tobaccoissues.com/candidatedetail.aspx?LegisID=CansXFra07301949 ]{{dead link|date=April 2016}}</ref> (born July 30, 1949)<ref name=CQRollGuide>{{cite news |title=Guide to the New Congress |date=2010-11-04 |url=http://innovation.cq.com/newmember/2010elexnguide.pdf |work=[[Roll Call|CQ Roll Call]] |accessdate=2010-11-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708200600/http://innovation.cq.com/newmember/2010elexnguide.pdf |archivedate=July 8, 2011}}</ref> is an attorney, businessman and former [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|TX|23}}. He is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].
==Early life and education== Canseco was born and reared in [[Laredo, Texas|Laredo]] in [[Webb County, Texas|Webb County]] in south [[Texas]], the eldest of eight children of Consuelo Sada Rangel and Dr. Francisco Manuel Canseco, who were both born in [[Monterrey]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com |title=RootsWeb: Freepages |website=Freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com |date= |accessdate=2016-04-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160412140132/http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/# |archive-date=2016-04-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Mexico]].<ref>[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/%7Ebattle/reps/canseco.htm "Quico Canseco"], Rootsweb</ref> He earned a B.A in History from [[Saint Louis University]] in 1972. He went on to earn a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] from [[Saint Louis University School of Law]] in 1975. He is a brother in the [[Tau Kappa Epsilon]] International Fraternity. His father was of Italian descent and his mother was of Sephardic Jewish descent.
==Legal/business career== Canseco began his legal career in 1975 as an [[associate attorney]] with Mann, Castillon, Fried and Kazen in Laredo. Afterwards, he operated his own practice for five years. Then he joined Person, Whitworth, Ramos, Borchers, and Morales in Laredo as a participating associate. In 1987, he left that firm to become [[general counsel]] at Union National Bank of Texas, where he stayed until 1992. He was later counsel to Escamilla and Ponek, from 2003 until 2007. He became chairman of Texas Heritage Bancshares from 2001 until 2007.
Since 1988, Canseco has been President/Director of FMC Developers, which includes Canseco Investments (incorporated in 1993). He, along with Chairman James William Danner, Sr., took Hondo National Bank from being a failing bank with $8 Million in assets and one location, to an institution with over $180 Million and four branches today. Canseco served as Board President since 1995.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://canseco.house.gov/index.cfm?sectionid=64&sectiontree=2,64 |title=Congressman Francisco Canseco: Biography |publisher=Canseco.house.gov |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2011}}</ref>
==U.S. House of Representatives==
===Elections=== [[Image:Quico Canseco.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Canseco at a campaign rally in San Antonio]]
;2004 {{Main|United States House of Representatives elections in Texas, 2004#District 28}} Canseco ran for the newly redrawn [[Texas' 28th congressional district]]. In the Republican primary, he and attorney Jim Hopson qualified for a run-off election. Canseco got just 21% of the vote, while Hopson got 49% of the vote (barely missing the 50% threshold to win the primary).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=5209 |title=TX – District 28 – R Primary Race – Mar 09, 2004 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2011}}</ref> In the run-off election, Hopson defeated Canseco 65%–35%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=81975 |title=TX – District 28 – R Runoff Race – Apr 13, 2004 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2011}}</ref>
;2008 {{Main|United States House of Representatives elections in Texas, 2008#District 23}} Canseco was defeated in the Republican primary by [[Bexar County, Texas|Bexar County]] Commissioner and former [[San Antonio]] city councilman [[Lyle Larson]] 62%–38%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsblaze.com/story/20080924165425tsop.nb/topstory.html|title=Democrat Fights to Retain Congressional Seat in Republican Texas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=402115 |title=TX – District 23 – R Primary Race – Mar 04, 2008 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2011}}</ref>
;2010 {{Main|United States House of Representatives elections in Texas, 2010#District 23}} In the Republican primary, Canseco and [[CIA officer]] [[Will Hurd]] qualified for a run-off election; Hurd got 34%, while Canseco got 32%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=612103 |title=TX District 23 – R Primary Race – Mar 02, 2010 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2011}}</ref> In the run-off, Canseco defeated Hurd 53%–47%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=634498 |title=TX District 23 – R Runoff Race – Apr 13, 2010 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2011}}</ref><ref name="state2">[http://enr.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/apr13_150_state.htm?x=0&y=540&id=215 Texas Secretary of State]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref>
In the general election, Canseco faced incumbent Democratic congressman [[Ciro Rodriguez]]. The Republican National Committee gave strong financial support to Canseco in an effort to regain the seat for the Republicans. As of October 13, 2010, Rodriguez had raised more cash overall ($1,481,520 versus Canseco's $980,821), but Canseco had more cash on hand ($147,961 versus Rodriguez's $90,915).<ref name=NYTimesProfile>{{cite news|title=Texas 23rd District Profile|date=2010-10-29|url=http://elections.nytimes.com/2010/house/texas/23|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate = 2010-10-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Gary|last=Martin|title=Quico Canseco only Texas challenger with more cash in bank than incumbent|date=2010-10-20|url=http://blogs.chron.com/txpotomac/2010/10/rodriguez_and_canseco_spending.html|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|accessdate = 2010-10-29}}</ref>
Canseco defeated Rodriguez 49%–44%.<ref name=TXSOS10>{{cite news|title=2010 General Election, Election Night Returns, Unofficial Elections Results As Of: 11/3/2010 12:14:58 PM |date=2010-11-03 |url=http://enr.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/nov02_154_state.htm?x=0&y=3608&id=179 |work=Texas Secretary of State |accessdate=2010-11-22 }}</ref>
;2012 {{Main|United States House of Representatives elections in Texas, 2012#District 23}} Ciro Rodriguez filed for a rematch with Canseco in 2012,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/pictures-video/trying-again-former-representatives-seeking-a-second-chance-pictures-20111122 |title=Trying Again: Former Representatives Seeking a Second Chance |publisher=National Journal |date=November 22, 2011 |accessdate=November 24, 2011}}</ref> but he lost the Democratic primary to State Representative [[Pete Gallego]], 55%–45%.
In the November 6 general election, Gallego defeated Canseco 50%–46%. Two minor candidates held the remaining 4.1% of the ballots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elections.sos.state.tx.us/elchist.exe |title=Archived copy |accessdate=December 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109062336/http://elections.sos.state.tx.us/elchist.exe |archivedate=January 9, 2014 }}</ref> The race was contested amid allegations of voter fraud and irregularities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Canseco not conceding congressional race|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/news/state-regional-govt-politics/canseco-not-conceding-congressional-race/nSzm2/}}</ref> On November 9, Canseco conceded to Gallego, citing the high costs and lengthy period of time required to contest the election. Although Canseco continued to allege numerous irregularities, he had concluded that "a full investigation and recount would be expensive and time-consuming," considering that the 23rd District embraces all or parts of 29 counties.<ref>Gary Martin, "Canseco calls Gallego on Friday to concede race", ''Laredo Morning Times'', November 10, 2012, p. 5A</ref> Canseco carried the district's portion of [[Bexar County]], home to more than half the district's population. However, it was not enough to overcome Gallego's margins in the central and western portions of the district, which were virtually coextensive with Gallego's old state House district. Gallego also dominated the heavily Hispanic border areas.
;2014 {{Main|United States House of Representatives elections in Texas, 2014#District 23}} In a bid to return to Congress, Canseco polled 10,204 votes (40.4%) in the Republican primary on March 4. He finished a close second to [[Will Hurd]], his intraparty rival from 2010. Hurd, an [[African American]], received 10,348 votes (49.9%). The remaining 4,723 votes (18.7%) went to a third candidate, Robert Lowry.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/mar04_169_state.htm?x=0&y=218&id=176|title=Republican primary election returns, March 4, 2014|publisher=enr.sos.state.tx.us|accessdate=March 5, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140305180619/https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/mar04_169_state.htm?x=0&y=218&id=176|archivedate=March 5, 2014|df=}}</ref> In the May 27 [[runoff election|runoff]] Hurd handily defeated Canseco, 8,698 (59.5%) to 5,924 (40.5%). Hurd faced freshman Democratic Representative Pete Gallego in the November 4 general election,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/may27_173_state.htm?x=0&y=1989&id=844|title=2014 Republican Party Primary Runoff: Election Night Returns|publisher=[[Texas Secretary of State]]|accessdate=May 28, 2014|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140528214950/https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/may27_173_state.htm?x=0&y=1989&id=844#|archive-date=2014-05-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and ultimately won.
When Canseco ran for Congress in 2010, he obtained two loans totaling $88,000 from his family-owned enterprises. The money was taken from a bank account of a subsidiary company with an address in Mexico. He also provided $86,000 in his own funds as a campaign loan. As Canseco runs in 2014, federal regulators are auditing his campaign funds to see if they are in violation of restrictions on corporate contributions and a longstanding ban on political donations made by foreign nationals, corporations, partnerships, and associations.<ref>Kevin Diaz of ''[[The Houston Chronicle]]'', "Texas's 23rd Congressional District: Feds audit Canseco's campaign finances", ''[[Laredo Morning Times'']], May 2, 2014, pp. 1, 10A</ref>
;2018 {{Main|United States House of Representatives elections in Texas, 2018#District 21}} In another bid to return to Congress, Canseco ran in the 18-way Republican primary for [[Texas's 21st congressional district]] to succeed the retiring incumbent Republican [[Lamar Smith]].<ref>http://herald-zeitung.com/article_f72d4ed0-1c1f-11e8-9ddb-d38ec48e53b4.html</ref> He was ultimately unsuccessful, garnering less than 5% of the vote.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/texas-house-district-21-primary-election</ref>
===Tenure===
Canseco describes himself as a "limited-government conservative."<ref>[http://cansecoforcongress.com/about Bio page on campaign site] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304070259/http://cansecoforcongress.com/about |date=March 4, 2011 }}.</ref>
He supports the [[Arizona immigration law]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Scott|last=Stroud|title=Election result will shape immigration reform|date=2010-10-27|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/politics/Election_result_will_shape_immigration_reform_105838338.html|work=[[San Antonio Express-News]]|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref> He supports the extension of the [[George W. Bush|Bush]] tax cuts and repealing the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. During the campaign, Canseco openly identified with the [[Tea Party movement]].<ref>{{cite news|first=James C.|last=McKinley, Jr.|title=In House Race in Texas, a Spotlight on the Hispanic Vote|date=2010-10-28|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/29/us/politics/29hispanics.html|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref>
Canseco was a member of the [[Republican Study Committee]], a caucus of conservative House Republicans. During his tenure, he was one of four voting Latino members of Congress known to be a member of the RSC, the others being [[Bill Flores]] of [[Texas]], [[Raul Labrador]] of [[Idaho]] and [[Jaime Herrera Beutler]] of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]. He was also a member of the [[Congressional Hispanic Conference]]. In 2012, Canseco delivered the Spanish language version of the Republican response to the State of the Union address.<ref>{{cite web|last=Martin |first=Gary |url=http://blog.chron.com/txpotomac/2012/01/julian-castro-and-quico-canseco-get-moment-in-spotlight-at-sotu/ |title=Julian Castro and Quico Canseco get moment in spotlight at SOTU - Texas on the Potomac |website=Blog.chron.com |date=2012-01-24 |accessdate=2016-04-06}}</ref>
In summer 2011, Canseco was criticized after initially declining to introduce a bill allowing for a swap of land between the Federal Government and Bexar County, Texas. The bill, which was supported by [[United States Secretary of the Interior]] [[Ken Salazar]] and sponsored by retiring Senator [[Kay Bailey Hutchison]] in the Senate, would expand the development of the [[San Antonio River]] to the [[San Antonio Missions National Historical Park]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Canseco is slow to move on Mission Park Expansion|date=2011-07-24|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/news_columnists/scott_stroud/article/Canseco-is-slow-to-move-on-Missions-park-expansion-1560374.php |work=[[San Antonio Express-News]]|accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref>
In October 2011, Canseco introduced the San Antonio Missions National Historical Park Boundary Expansion Act in the House, which mirrored Hutchison's Senate bill.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.chron.com/txpotomac/2011/11/san-antonio-missions-national-park-bill-approved-by-senate-panel/|title=San Antonio Missions national park bill approved by Senate panel}}</ref> The legislation would cost roughly $4 million over four years, even though the lands would be donated.
In April 2012, Canseco traveled using the San Antonio International Airport. He said that he was assaulted by the [[Transportation Security Administration]] when an officer "was patting me down where no one is supposed to go." The TSA officer said that he was assaulted by Canseco, but no arrests were made. Canseco advocates for changes in security procedures.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kens5.com/news/local/I-TEAM--Congressman-Canseco-says-TSA-agent-assaulted-him-during-a-pat-down-148756365.html |title=Congressman says he was assaulted during pat-down |accessdate=2012-04-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427192631/http://www.kens5.com/news/local/I-TEAM--Congressman-Canseco-says-TSA-agent-assaulted-him-during-a-pat-down-148756365.html |archivedate=April 27, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Canseco reportedly voted with his party 96% of the time on all issues.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://projects.washingtonpost.com/congress/members/C001082|title= Quico Canseco (R)|author= |date= |work= Washington Post|publisher= |accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref>
===Committee assignments=== * '''[[United States House Committee on Financial Services|Committee on Financial Services]]''' ** [[United States House Financial Services Subcommittee on Financial Institutions and Consumer Credit|Subcommittee on Financial Institutions and Consumer Credit]] ** [[United States House Financial Services Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations|Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations]]
==Personal life== Canseco and his wife, Gloria, have been married since 1979. The couple resides in [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]]. They have three children and attend St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cansecoforcongress.com/about |title=Canseco for Congress |publisher=Canseco for Congress |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016221632/http://www.cansecoforcongress.com/about |archivedate=October 16, 2011 }}</ref> He attended [[Culver Academies|Culver Military Academy]] in his youth.
==Electoral history==

Blunt |votes = 5,827 |percentage = 3.04 }} {{Election box candidate with party link no change |party = Green Party (US) |candidate = Ed Scharf |votes = 2,099 |percentage = 1.09 }} {{Election box total no change |votes = 191,658 |percentage = 5.89 }} {{Election box end}}

{{infobox criminal | name = Robert Melson | birth_date = Robert Bryant Melson
{{birth date|1971|6|5}} | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|6|8|1971|6|5}} | death_place = [[Atmore, Alabama|Atmore,]] [[Alabama]], U.S. | victims = Tamika Collins, 18
Nathaniel Baker, 17
Darrell Collier, 23 | date = April 15, 1994 | charge = [[Capital murder]] | penalty = [[Death penalty|Death]] (May 17, 1996) }} {{for|the professor emeritus of political science at Purdue University|Robert Melson}} '''Robert Bryant Melson''' (June 5, 1971 – June 8, 2017) was an Alabama inmate who was sentenced to death and executed{{cite web|url=http://www.doc.state.al.us/DeathRow.aspx|title=Alabama Department of Corrections|website=Doc.state.al.us|accessdate=30 July 2017}} for the 1994 murders of three workers at a [[Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen Inc.|Popeyes]] restaurant in [[Gadsden, Alabama|Gadsden]]. ==The crime== On the night of Friday, April 15, 1994, Melson and his accomplice Cuhuatemoc Hinricky Peraita (born May 19, 1976) entered a Popeyes restaurant in east Gadsden through the back door of the building after employee Darrell K. Collier unlocked it to allow fellow employees Nathaniel Baker and Bryant Archer to take out the trash. Upon entry, Melson and Peraita ordered Archer, Baker, Collier, and fourth employee Tamika Collins into the restaurant's office and demanded that they empty the safe. They complied, after which Melson ordered the four to get inside the restaurant's freezer. Shortly after locking them in the freezer, Melson unlocked the door and opened fire. Baker, Collier and Collins all died of their wounds before paramedics arrived. Archer was shot four times, but he survived and was able to crawl to the restaurant's office to call 911.{{cite web|url=http://www.cncpunishment.com/forums/showthread.php?1175-Robert-Bryant-Melson-Alabama-Execution-June-8-2017&p=1526&viewfull=1#post1526|title=Robert Bryant Melson - Alabama Execution - June 8, 2017|website=Cncpunishment.com|accessdate=2017-07-30}} ==Legal proceedings== Melson was convicted of his role in the crime and sentenced to death on May 17, 1996, and he was placed on death row under [[Alabama Department of Corrections]] ID 0000Z601. Peraita was sentenced to life without parole, but he killed a fellow inmate on December 11, 1999, for which he received a death sentence in October 2001. Melson had two execution dates set in 2010, both of which were stayed. On April 5, 2017, Melson had an execution date set for [[List of offenders executed in the United States in 2017|June 8, 2017]].{{cite web|url=https://deathpenaltyinfo.org/upcoming-executions|title=Upcoming Executions - Death Penalty Information Center|website=deathpenaltyinfo.org|accessdate=30 July 2017}} He received a temporary stay from an appellate court on June 2, but the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] vacated the stay on June 6 without comment. At 5:45 pm on the night of the execution, the U.S. Supreme Court granted a temporary stay so Justice [[Clarence Thomas]] could review Melson's appeals. The stay was later lifted and the execution began at 9:55 pm. Melson was pronounced dead at 10:27 pm.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/robert-melson-executed-in-alabama-for-94-triple-murder-during-robbery/|title=Robert Melson executed in Alabama for '94 triple murder during robbery|website=Cbsnews.com|accessdate=30 July 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Melson, Robert}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:1994 murders in the United States]] [[Category:21st-century executions by Alabama]] [[Category:21st-century executions of American people]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Executed African-American people]] [[Category:Male murderers]] [[Category:American murderers]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Alabama]] [[Category:People executed by Alabama by lethal injection]] [[Category:People executed for murder]]

[[File:TrelawnyArms.png|thumb|Arms of Trelawny: ''Argent, a chevron sable''<ref>Kidd, Charles, ''Debrett's peerage & Baronetage'' 2015 Edition, London, 2015, p.B796</ref>]] The '''Trelawny''', later '''Salusbury-Trelawny Baronetcy''', of [[Trelawny, Pelynt|Trelawny]] in the County of [[Cornwall]], is a title in the [[Baronetage of England]]. It was created on 1 July 1628 for [[Sir John Trelawny, 1st Baronet|John Trelawny]] of [[Trelawny, Pelynt|Trelawny]] in the parish of [[Pelynt]] in Cornwall.<ref name=Cokayne>{{Citation| editor-last=Cokayne| editor-first=George Edward |year=1902 | title= Complete Baronetage volume 2 (1625-1649) | url= http://www.archive.org/stream/cu31924092524382#page/n61/mode/2up | location=Exeter | publisher=William Pollard and Co| pages= 43| accessdate = 9 October 2018}}</ref> The family derived much of their political power from their patronage of the nearby [[pocket borough]] of [[East Looe (UK Parliament constituency)|East Looe]].<ref>[[History of Parliament]]: House of Commons 1715-1754, ed. R. Sedgwick, 1970[http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1715-1754/constituencies/east-looe]</ref> The second Baronet sat as [[Member of Parliament]] for [[East Looe (UK Parliament constituency)|East Looe]], [[Cornwall (UK Parliament constituency)|Cornwall]] and [[Liskeard (UK Parliament constituency)|Liskeard]]. The third Baronet was a clergyman and one of the [[Seven Bishops]] imprisoned by [[James II of England|James II]]. The fourth Baronet represented [[West Looe (UK Parliament constituency)|West Looe]], [[Liskeard]] and [[East Looe]] in the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]]. The fifth Baronet was Member of Parliament for East Looe. The sixth Baronet sat as Member of Parliament for West Looe and served as [[Governor of Jamaica]]. The eighth Baronet was [[Member of Parliament]] for [[East Cornwall (UK Parliament constituency)|East Cornwall]] 1832–1837 and [[Lord-Lieutenant of Cornwall]]. In 1802 he assumed the additional surname of Salusbury. The ninth Baronet represented [[Tavistock (UK Parliament constituency)|Tavistock]] and [[East Cornwall (UK Parliament constituency)|East Cornwall]] in [[Parliament]].
[[John Trelawny (died 1680)|John Trelawny]], [[Charles Trelawny]] and [[Henry Trelawny]], sons of the second Baronet and brothers of the third Baronet, all gained distinction in their own right. [[Edward Trelawny (governor)|Edward Trelawny]], younger son of [[Sir Jonathan Trelawny, 3rd Baronet|Bishop Trelawny (3rd Bt)]], served as [[Governor of Jamaica]] 1738-52.
==Trelawny, later Salusbury-Trelawny baronets, of Trelawny (1628)== *[[Sir John Trelawny, 1st Baronet]] (1592–1664) *[[Sir Jonathan Trelawny, 2nd Baronet]] ({{circa|1623}}–1681) *[[Sir Jonathan Trelawny, 3rd Baronet]] (1650–1721) *[[Sir John Trelawny, 4th Baronet]] (1691–1756) *[[Sir Harry Trelawny, 5th Baronet]] (1687–1762) *[[Sir William Trelawny, 6th Baronet]] ({{circa|1722–}}1772) *Sir Harry Trelawny, 7th Baronet (1756–1834) *[[Sir William Salusbury-Trelawny, 8th Baronet|Sir William Lewis Salusbury-Trelawny, 8th Baronet]] (1781–1856) *[[Sir John Salusbury-Trelawny, 9th Baronet|Sir John Salusbury Salusbury-Trelawny, 9th Baronet]] (1816–1885) *Sir William Lewis Salusbury-Trelawny, 10th Baronet (1844–1917) *Sir John William Salusbury-Trelawny, 11th Baronet (1869–1944) *Sir John William Robin Maurice Salusbury-Trelawny, 12th Baronet (1908–1956) *Sir John Barry Salusbury-Trelawny, 13th Baronet (1934–2009) *Sir John William Richard Salusbury-Trelawny, 14th Baronet (born 1960)<ref>[http://thepeerage.com/p57153.htm#i571528 www.thepeerage.com]</ref> **The [[heir apparent]] to the baronetcy is the son of the 14th baronet, Harry John Salusbury-Trelawny (born 1982).<ref>[http://www.burkespeerage.com/ ''Burke's Peerage & Baronetage'']</ref>
