'''William Erwin Paul''' (June 12, 1936 – September 18, 2015) was an American immunologist.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Germain|first1=Ronald N.|title=William E. Paul (1936–2015): A leading force in immunology.|journal=Nature|date=October 14, 2015|volume=526|issue=324|subscription=yes|doi=10.1038/526324a|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v526/n7573/full/526324a.html?WT.ec_id=NATURE-20151015|accessdate=November 21, 2015}}</ref> He and Maureen Johnson discovered [[interleukin 4]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=Howard M, Paul WE |title=Interleukins for B lymphocytes |journal=Lymphokine Res. |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=1–4 |year=1982 |pmid=6985399 |doi=}}</ref><ref name=nyt>{{cite news|last1=Roberts|first1=Sam|title=Dr. William E. Paul, Who Helped AIDS Research Save Millions of Lives, Dies at 79|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/23/science/dr-william-e-paul-who-helped-aids-research-save-millions-of-lives-dies-at-79.html|accessdate=September 26, 2015|work=New York Times|date=September 22, 2015}}</ref> while an independent team led by [[Ellen Vitetta]] did the same in 1982. Paul worked on [[AIDS research]] for much of his career at the [[National Institutes of Health]] (NIH).<ref name=nyt/> He served as president of the [[American Association of Immunologists]] from 1986 to 1987.<ref name=aaioh>{{cite news|title=William E. Paul, M.D. (1936–2015) Oral History|url=http://www.aai.org/about/History/Notable_Members/Presidents/Paul_William.html|accessdate=September 26, 2015|agency=American Association of Immunologists|date=April 18, 2012|archivedate=April 18, 2012|archiveurl=http://www.aai.org/about/History/Notable_Members/pdfs/OHP/Transcripts/Trans-Inv_001-Paul_William_E-2012_Final.pdf|last1=Williams|first1=Brien}}</ref>
==Background== Paul's father Jack immigrated to the United States from Ukraine with his mother and younger siblings in 1911 to join his father and other family members. While in America, Jack Paul met and married Sylvia Gleicher, a cousin of [[Norman Geschwind]]. Their son William Erwin Paul was born in [[Brooklyn, New York]] on June 12, 1936. William Paul attended [[Erasmus Hall High School]] and graduated from Andrew Jackson High School, Queens, New York. William Paul graduated from [[Brooklyn College]] in 1956 before earning a medical degree from [[SUNY Downstate College of Medicine]] four years later.<ref name=nyt/><ref name=aaioh/>
==Career== Paul did his residency at the [[Boston Medical Center]] and [[National Cancer Institute]] (NCI). He joined the [[United States Public Health Service Commissioned Corps]] in 1962 and was assigned to the Endocrinology Branch of the NCI, where he worked for two years. Paul read the writings of [[Michael Heidelberger]], and decided to train as an immunologist. A desire to collaborate with rheumatologist Alan Cohen influenced his decision as well. Paul trained at [[New York University]] with [[Baruj Benacerraf]] and later moved with him to the [[National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases]] (NIAID). He succeeded Benacerraf as NIH immunology laboratory director in 1970. Upon the establishment of NIH's Office of AIDS Research in 1993, Paul was chosen as its first leader. He stepped down from that position in 1997. He also helped found NIAID's [[Vaccine Research Center]].<ref name=nyt/><ref name=aaioh/> Paul was the chief editor of the ''[[Annual Review of Immunology]]'' from 1983 to 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=NIH Mourns William E. Paul, Pioneering Immunologist and Laboratory Chief|url=http://www.niaid.nih.gov/news/newsreleases/2015/Pages/PaulObituary.aspx|accessdate=September 27, 2015|agency=National Insititute of Health|date=September 22, 2015}}</ref> He received the 2002 [[American Association of Immunologists Lifetime Achievement Award]]<ref name="Winners">{{cite web | title=Past Recipients | website=The American Association of Immunologists | url=https://www.aai.org/Awards/Career-Awards/AAI-Lifetime-Achievement-Award/Past-Recipients.aspx | access-date=19 September 2018}}</ref> and the 2008 [[Max Delbrück Medal]].<ref>{{cite news|title=US Immunologist William E. Paul Receives the Max Delbrück Medal|url=https://www.mdc-berlin.de/18481760/en/news/archive/2008/20081113-us_immunologist_william_e__paul_receives_t|accessdate=September 27, 2015|agency=[[Max Delbrück Center for Molecular Medicine in the Helmholtz Association]]|date=November 13, 2008}}</ref>
Paul was adjunct professor at the [[University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine]] and the Raymond and Beverly Sackler Senior Professor at [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Biography: William E. Paul|url=http://www.fpid.org/paul|accessdate=September 27, 2015|publisher=Foundation for Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases}}</ref>
He died in Manhattan of [[acute myeloid leukemia]] on September 18, 2015, aged 79.<ref name=nyt/>

as Royal Governor | successor = [[Elisha Lawrence]]
Acting Governor | birth_date = {{birth date|1723|11|30|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Albany, New York|Albany]], [[Province of New York]], [[British America]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1790|7|25|1723|11|30|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]], U.S. | resting_place = [[Green-Wood Cemetery]], [[Brooklyn, New York]] | spouse = {{marriage|Susannah French
|1745|1789|reason=her death}} | parents = [[Philip Livingston (1686-1749)|Philip Livingston]]
Catherine Van Brugh | children = 13, including [[Brockholst Livingston|Brockholst]] | alma_mater = [[Yale College]] | relatives = See [[Livingston family]] }} '''William Livingston''' (November 30, 1723{{spaced ndash}}July 25, 1790) was an American politician who served as the [[Governor of New Jersey]] (1776–1790) during the [[American Revolutionary War]] and was a signer of the [[United States Constitution]]. ==Early life== Livingston was born in [[Albany, New York|Albany]] in the [[Province of New York]] on November 30, 1723. He was the son of [[Philip Livingston (1686-1749)|Philip Livingston]] (1686–1749), the 2nd Lord of [[Livingston Manor]], and Catherine Van Brugh, the only child of [[List of mayors of Albany, New York|Albany mayor]] [[Pieter Van Brugh]] (1666–1740). His older siblings included [[Robert Livingston (1708–1790)|Robert Livingston]] (1708–1790), 3rd Lord of Livingston Manor, [[Peter Van Brugh Livingston]] (1710–1792), [[New York State Treasurer]], and [[Philip Livingston]] (1716–1778), a member of the [[New York State Senate]]. Livingston received his early education from local schools and tutors. At age 13, Livingston was sent to live for a year and prepare for college with the Anglican missionary catechist and [[Yale College]] graduate Henry Barclay who lived among the Iroquois Indians in the [[Mohawk Valley]] at [[Fort Hunter]].Dexter, Franklin Bowditch, ''Biographical sketches of the graduates of Yale College: with annals of the college'', Holt, 1885, Volume 1, pp.503–504 Livingston enrolled at Yale in 1737 and graduated in 1741. He went on to New York City, where he studied law and became a law clerk first for the eminent lawyer [[James Alexander (lawyer)|James Alexander]]. He left Alexander's office in the spring of 1746 before finishing his apprentiship due to some disagreement,Dexter, p.682 and joined the office [[William Smith (judge)|William Smith, Sr]].{{cite book| url = http://www.history.army.mil/books/RevWar/ss/livingston.htm | title = Soldier-Statesmen of the Constitution| id =CMH Pub 71-25| chapter = William Livingston| location = Washington, DC| publisher=United States Army Center of Military History| first1 =Robert K.| last1 = Wright, Jr.|first2= Morris J.| last2 = MacGregor Jr.| last-author-amp=yes}} ==Career== He became a lawyer in 1748Dexter, p. 682 and began his practice in [[New York City]]. In 1752, he founded a weekly journal, the ''[[Independent Reflector]]'', along with fellow Presbyterian lawyers [[William Smith (chief justice)|William Smith, Jr.]], the son of his law teacher, and [[John Morin Scott]]. The three were called by contemporaries "The Triumvirate".Lustig, Mary Lou, ''Privilege and Prerogative: New York's Provincial Elite, 1710–1776'',Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press, 1995, p. 83 The ''Reflector'' was New York's first serial non-newspaper publication and the only one being published in British North America at the time. It was used as a platform by the political upstate Presbyterian landed "country faction" led by Livingston for challenging the powerful downstate Anglican and Dutch Reformed merchant or "popular faction" led by chief justice [[James De Lancey]]. Most notably the Triumvirate attacked the founding of [[Columbia College, Columbia University|King's College]] as a conspiracy by Anglicans to install a bishop in America, including his former tutor now Rev. Henry Barclay Rector of Trinity Church and his former law teacher James Alexander. Publication of the ''Reflector'' ceased with the fifty-second issue in late 1753 after political pressure was brought to bear upon its printer, [[James Parker (publisher)|James Parker]], but Livingston and his allies continued to attack the college over the next year with columns in newspapers.McCaughey, Robert A., ''Stand, Columbia : a history of Columbia University in the city of New York, 1754–2004'', Columbia University Press, 2003, pp. 18–19 By raising divisive issues of region, he managed to divert half the funds raised by a state lottery for the college to fund the construction of a new jail and a detention house for sailors from diseased ships. King's College was defiantly opened despite Livingston's efforts by [[Samuel Johnson (American educator)|President Rev. Samuel Johnson]] in July 1754, and granted a charter by the King on October 31, 1754.McCaughey, pp. 21–22 Though he failed to close the college, and no bishop arrived as predicted, Livingston remained politically active and served one term in the [[New York Assembly]] until his political allies lost power in 1769. === New Jersey === In 1772, he moved to [[Elizabeth, New Jersey#History|Elizabethtown]] (today [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]]), where he rented a house in town. A young [[Alexander Hamilton]] lived here with Livingston for at least the winter while he attended Francis Barber's grammar school.Hamilton John C., ''The Life of Alexander Hamilton'', D. Appleton, 1840, Volume 1, p.8; Hamilton John C., History of the Republic, D. Appleton & Company, 1857, Volume 1, p. 46{{Cite news|url=http://discoveringhamilton.com/alexander-hamilton-lived-grammar-school-elizabethtown-new-jersey/|title=Where Did Alexander Hamilton Live While Attending Grammar School in Elizabethtown, New Jersey? – Discovering Hamilton|date=2018-01-22|work=Discovering Hamilton|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en-US}} Livingston started construction of a large country home to house his growing family. The house, known as ''[[Liberty Hall (New Jersey)|Liberty Hall]]'', still stands today. After attaining considerable influence amongst the local patriots, Livingston was elected to serve as one of New Jersey's delegates to the [[Continental Congress]]. He served from July 1774 to June 1776. In October 1775, he was commissioned a [[brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] of the [[New Jersey Line|New Jersey Militia]]. [[File:William Livingston 1778.jpg|thumb|Letter from Governor William Livingston to Israel Shreve, 1778]] In August 1776, he was elected [[Governor of New Jersey]] and was reelected to the office each year until his death in 1790. For much of the time between 1776 and 1779, the family was located in [[Parsippany, New Jersey|Parsippany]] for safety. Liberty Hall was frequently visited by British troops or naval forces since there was a substantial reward for Livingston's capture. One attempt to kidnap him took place in mid-June 1779. False information about Livingston visiting his second home in Parsippany resulted in a raid by Loyalists and their subsequent capture. The Loyalist mayor of New York City (and a distant cousin through the [[Schuyler family]]), [[David Mathews]], was suspected by being behind the attempted capture of Livingston.McBurney, Christian. Abductions in the American Revolution, 2016, page 74 The family returned to Liberty Hall in 1779 to begin restoring their looted home. He was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1782.{{cite web |title=Book of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter L |url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterL.pdf |publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} ===Later years=== Livingston led the New Jersey Delegation to the [[Philadelphia Convention|1787 Constitutional Convention]] in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] and was one of the signers of the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]]. He was appointed [[United States Ambassador to the Netherlands|United States Minister to the Netherlands]] in 1788 by U.S. Congress but turn down the proposition. ==Personal life== Livingston married Susannah French (1723–1789) in New Jersey in 1745. She was the daughter of landowner, Philip French III and Susanna ([[née]] Brockholst) French. Her paternal grandparents were [[Phillip French]], the 27th [[Mayor of New York City]], and Annetje (née Philipse) French (the daughter of [[Frederick Philipse]]). Her maternal grandparents were Susanna Maria Brockholst and [[Anthony Brockholls|Anthony Brockholst]], an acting [[List of colonial governors of New York|Governor of Colonial New York]] under Sir [[Edmund Andros]].{{cite web|title=Susannah French Livingston|url=https://www.womenhistoryblog.com/2009/01/susannah-french-livingston.html|website=womenhistoryblog.com|publisher=History of American Women|accessdate=16 November 2017|date=30 January 2009}}{{cite book|last1=Hoffman|first1=Samuel Verplanck|title=Collections of The New-York Historical Society for the Year 1902 {{!}} Publication Fund Series|date=1903|publisher=Printed for the Society|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6CAXAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA91&lpg=PA91|page=91|accessdate=16 November 2017|language=en}} They went on to have 13 children, including:{{cite web |url=https://www.archives.gov/exhibits/charters/constitution_founding_fathers_new_jersey.html |title=America's Founding Fathers – Delegates to the Constitutional Convention: New Jersey |author= |publisher=U.S. National Archives & Records Administration |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160606141057/http://archives.gov/exhibits/charters/constitution_founding_fathers_new_jersey.html |archive-date= June 6, 2016 |dead-url=no }}{{cite book |last1=Livingston |first1=Edwin Brockholst |title=The Livingstons of Livingston Manor: Being the History of that Branch of the Scottish House of Callendar which Settled in the English Province of New York During the Reign of Charles the Second; and Also Including an Account of Robert Livingston of Albany, "The Nephew," a Settler in the Same Province and His Principal Descendants |date=1910 |publisher=The Knickerbocker Press |location=New York |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yk5mAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage|accessdate=November 16, 2017 |language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Reynolds|first1=Cuyler|title=Genealogical and Family History of Southern New York and the Hudson River Valley: A Record of the Achievements of Her People in the Making of a Commonwealth and the Building of a Nation|date=1914|publisher=Lewis Historical Publishing Company|pages=1335–1336|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iNIUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1335&lpg=PA1335|accessdate=16 November 2017|language=en}} * Livingston (1746–1746), a son who died in infancy. * Livingston (1747–1747), another son who died in infancy. * Susannah Livingston (1748–1840), who married [[John Cleves Symmes]] (1742–1814) in 1780 and became the stepmother-in-law of [[President of the United States|President]] [[William Henry Harrison]]. * Catherine Livingston (1751–1813), who married Matthew Ridley (1746–1789), and later, her cousin John Livingston (1750–1822), son of [[Robert Livingston (1708–1790)|Robert Livingston]]. * Mary Livingston (b. 1753), who married James Linn in May 1771. * William Livingston, Jr. (1754–1817), who married Mary Lennington. * Philip Van Brugh Livingston (b. 1755), who died unmarried. * [[Sarah Livingston Jay|Sarah Van Brugh Livingston]] (1756–1802), who married [[John Jay]] (1745–1829) and became [[First Lady of the United States]] while Jay served as the President of the [[Continental Congress]] from 1778–1779. * [[Brockholst Livingston|Henry Brockholst Livingston]] (1757–1823), an [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States]] who married 3 times. * Judith Livingston (1758–1843), who married John W. Watkins, an attorney.{{cite book|last1=Rapelje|first1=George|title=A Narrative of Excursions, Voyages, and Travels, Performed at Different Periods in America, Europe, Asia, and Africa|date=1834|page=12|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_IcBAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=16 November 2017|language=en}} * Philip French Livingston (b. 1760), who drowned in the [[Hackensack River]]. * John Lawrence Livingston (1762–1781), who died at sea aboard the ''[[USS Saratoga (1780)|USS Saratoga]]''. * Elizabeth Clarkson Livingston (1764–1765), who died young. Livingston died on July 25, 1790 in [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]], and was originally buried at [[Trinity Church (Manhattan)|Trinity Church]], [[Manhattan]], but on May 7, 1844 was reinterred at [[Green-Wood Cemetery]], [[Brooklyn]]. ===Descendants=== Livingston's daughter, Sarah, was born in 1756 and was educated at home in penmanship, English grammar, the Bible, and classic literature. At a time when women were usually relegated to the kitchen, she was brought up to be politically aware, even serving at times as her father's secretary.[http://www.sarahlivingstonjay.org/ About Sarah Livingston Jay]. Accessed October 13, 2014. who married [[John Jay]] at the age of 17 and became United States [[First Lady]] (age 22) while Jay served as the President of the [[Continental Congress]] from 1778–1779. Sarah accompanied [[John Jay]] to Spain and then [[Paris]] where he, along with [[John Adams]], [[Benjamin Franklin]], and [[Henry Laurens]] negotiated the [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|Treaty of Paris]]. She is credited with writing the celebratory Treaty of Paris dinner toast. When Sarah and John returned to New York, Jay was appointed U.S. Foreign Secretary, and her Parisian training came in handy, as she and her husband established the custom of weekly dinners for the diplomatic corps and other guests in the U.S. capital city of New York. Sarah would go on to serve in her hospitality role as the wife of the first [[Chief Justice of the United States]] and First Lady of New York. Another descendant of William Livingston was Julia Kean, wife of [[United States Secretary of State]] and [[New York Governor]] [[Hamilton Fish]]. ===Legacy=== In 1747, Livingston wrote and published a long pastoral poem entitled, "Philosophic Solitude, or the Choice of a Rural Life". One of the first successful original poems written by an American colonist, it was anthologized numerous times into the 19th century. In 1754, Livingston also played a key role in founding the [[New York Society Library]], which is still in existence over a quarter of a millennium later. The township of [[Livingston, New Jersey]] was given its name in his honor,[http://www.livingstonnj.org/livingstonhistory.htm About Livingston] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727041002/http://www.livingstonnj.org/livingstonhistory.htm |date=July 27, 2011 }}. Accessed March 9, 2007. as was [[Governor Livingston High School]] in [[Berkeley Heights, New Jersey]]. The [[Livingston Campus (Rutgers University)|Livingston campus]] of Rutgers University New Brunswick also was given its name in his honor. ==See also== * [[Livingston family]] * [[Isaac Collins (printer)]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{CongBio|L000374}} * {{cite EB1911 |wstitle=Livingston, William |volume=16 |page=813 |short=x}} * [http://www.nga.org/cms/home/governors/past-governors-bios/page_new_jersey/col2-content/main-content-list/title_livingston_william.html New Jersey Governor William Livingston], [[National Governors Association]] * [https://archive.org/details/philosophicSolitude1747ByWilliamLivingston "PHILOSOPHIC SOLITUDE" (1747) by William Livingston] * {{Find a Grave|10672476}} – [[cenotaph]] at Trinity Churchyard * {{FAG|3278}} – Green-Wood Cemetery * [http://www.green-wood.com/burial_results/index.php Green-Wood Cemetery Burial Search] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=[[List of Governors of New Jersey|Governor of New Jersey]]|before=[[William Franklin]]

{{Infobox scientist | name = Ying-Cheng Lai | image = | birth_name =Ying-Cheng Lai | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | fields = [[Math]] and [[Physics]] ([[Theoretical physics|theoretical]]) | workplaces = [[University of Maryland, College Park]] | alma_mater = {{Plainlist| *Zhejiang University * University of Maryland. *Arizona State University. }} | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | awards = | religion = | footnotes = }} '''Ying-Cheng Lai''' is a Chinese theoretical physicist who works in the area of chaos theory. He is one among the pioneers in the nonlinear and complex systems and chaos theory. Currently he works in Arizona State University holding an ISS Chair Professorship.
==Research areas==
Ying-Cheng Lai has worked in the fields of dynamics of nonlinear and complex systems including [[Chaos Theory|chaotic dynamics]], [[Quantum chaos|relativistic quantum chaotic dynamics]], [[complex networks]], [[computational biology]] and [[graphene]] physics. He has coauthored several scientific articles with [[Celso Grebogi]], [[Edward Ott]], [[James A. Yorke]] and [[Miguel Angel Fernández Sanjuán|Miguel A. F. Sanjuán]]. He has directed 19 Ph.D. and 20 master theses and supported 14 post-doctoral fellows.
==Awards== In 1997, From the White House, he had received the Air Force Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers (PECASE) . Also in the same year the National Science Foundation honored him with a Faculty Career Award. In 2008, he received the Outstanding Referee Award from the American Physical Society. In 2016, he was chosen as the 2016 class of National Security Science and Engineering Faculty Fellows, Pentagon officials announced. This program awards grants to top-tier researchers from U.S. universities to conduct long-term, unclassified, basic research of strategic importance to the Defense Department.<ref>http://www.defense.gov/News-Article-View/Article/704082/dod-announces-national-security-science-and-engineering-faculty-fellows</ref>
==Books== *Ying-Cheng Lai and Tamas Tel ''Transient Chaos: complex dynamics in finite time scales'', Springer.
